The Nature and Significance of CNO\nIn the following paragraphs, the various forms and effects of CNO will be examined (1). Next, the challenge of the attribution of a cyber attack will be discussed (2). Finally, the significance of CNO for the conduct of military operations in the context of contemporary armed conflicts will be addressed (3).\n## 1. Forms and Effects of CNO\nThe concept of CNO covers the following activities: defence against a cyber attack launched against one’s own computer networks (Computer Network Defence – CND), information and intelligence gathering from adversary computer networks (Computer Network Exploitation – CNE) and the conduct of a cyber attack against adversary’s computer networks (Computer Network Attack – CNA).\nThe above-mentioned components of CNO are strongly interrelated. An adversary’s CNA can help one’s own CND when analysed appropriately. A CNE cannot be conducted without CNA, as the information to be gathered by CNE will mostly be protected by firewalls, passwords and other barriers that are erected to prevent an adversarial CNA. Finally, CNA cannot be conducted without CNE, as without information gathering on the targeted network’s architecture and systems the CNA would effectively be conducted blindly.\nWhile the practical value of the taxonomy of CND/CNE/CNA therefore is questionable, it will be presented in more detail below as most academic writings and media reports refer to this classification.\n## A. CND\nCND is the protection of one’s own computer systems against cyber attacks or illegal access. It includes protection of access to the networks, e.g. by passwords, the constant analysis of all hacking efforts and the continuous improvement of security standards. These improvements can comprise particular security settings in one’s own operating systems (e.g. closing of identified security gaps), establishment of respective network protection structures (e.g. individual assignment of so-called ports, i.e. “entrance/exit doors” for data streams) and firewalls, the installation of special software detecting intrusions and, if available, a honey net (i.e. a computer network established outside and around\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\none’s own network serving as a *quasi* buffer zone). The terms “active defence in cyberspace” or “active CND”, every now and then used in media reports or even military policies, merely refers to launching a cyber counter-attack against the cyber attacker’s computer networks, thus using means of CNA.\n## B. CNE\nAccording to NATO’s Glossary of Terms and Definitions, CNE is an “action taken to make use of a computer or computer network, as well as the information hosted therein, in order to gain advantage”. This kind of “electronic intelligence gathering” aims at information about the architecture of the targeted network (*network-mapping*), the operating system data (*footprinting*) and, finally, all data saved in adversary systems, which contain information in the common sense. Consequently, CNE should be considered as a form of modern electronic espionage.\nAccording to open source reports, the vast majority of CNO activities conducted during peacetime consist of CNE. For example, already in 2007, the British intelligence service MI5 warned all financial service providers and companies in Great Britain against concerted cyber espionage endeavours by the Chinese People’s Liberation Army. In summer 2007, the computer systems of Germany’s Federal Chancellery as well as those of some federal ministries were infected with spyware (i.e. espionage software) reported to have originated from China. According to the Annual Report 2009 of the German Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, computer systems of Germany’s federal and state governments and of private businesses were targeted by hundreds of (successful and/or unsuccessful) CNE. Foreign intelligence\n\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\nservices were likely to be the organizers of, or are involved in, most of these. In the USA, over 100 foreign intelligence services currently endeavour to intrude computer systems located in the country, as the US Deputy Secretary of Defence stated in September 2010. NATO’s computer networks are also subject to constant – and partly successful – CNE.\nThere is no open source information as to the employment of CNE during an armed conflict. However, it can be assumed that CNE is very likely to be used in support of military intelligence, reconnaissance and surveillance.\n## C. CNA\nCNA can cause multiple effects. NATO’s Glossary of Terms and Definitions defines CNA as an “action taken to disrupt, deny, degrade or destroy information resident in a computer and/or computer network, or the computer and/or computer network itself”. These are all forms of manipulation, suppression or deletion of data in adversary networks, or the delay, suppression or interruption of data transfer processes. The methods, means and techniques of CNA are manifold (e.g. breaking of passwords, injecting malware). The effects can involve either the system or the user level (e.g. delay or interruption of data transfer) and can indirectly cause physical damage outside the targeted computer networks.\nRelatively harmless, data modification in the course of a CNA can modify and deface a website (defacement). This is often conducted by hackers who wish to express their political view (hacktivism). Another widely spread form of CNA is the Distributed-Denial-of-Service attack\n\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\n(DDoS-attack), which can cause delays in the data transfer process, the denial of access to computer systems or servers (e.g. the targeted websites or a email service) or result in the (only temporary) disabling of the targeted systems. The particular DDoS-techniques are as diverse as the – partly very effective – countermeasures developed since 2000.\nHowever, the deletion or modification of data in a successfully intruded computer network can be more hazardous. Hackers can generate wrong information, for instance in the military environment the content of electronically transmitted orders, plans and maps or the localization data of military targets contained in a targeting-database.\nMoreover, it is possible that a CNA could – indirectly – cause death, physical injury or physical destruction of property. As far as chemical plants, nuclear power stations, oil refinery installations, gas store installations or electrical power distribution installations have or rely on computer-based control systems, these systems could be penetrated and manipulated. Thus, a CNA could cause the explosion of a nuclear power plant if the cooling systems were disabled via remote control. The same applies to computer-based control systems of transportation systems. By manipulation of the rail points, train derailments or collisions could be caused; penetration and minimal amendments to the programming of an air traffic control system could result in aircraft incidents. Therefore, the classification of CNO as a non-lethal weapon, as asserted by some scholars, has to be challenged in this regard. Also, the general assertion made that CNO, in its current form would generally not violate LOAC, is questionable.\n\nAbove all, CNA can affect the functioning of a State, when manipulating or deleting data in computer systems of critical infrastructure systems. The list of critical infrastructure systems will slightly differ from State to State. By way of example, the following areas identified by the German Federal Office of Security of Information Technology (Bundesamt für Sicherheit in der Informationstechnik) can be considered as critical infrastructure systems: transportation and traffic (postal services, local traffic, roads, rail system, aviation, sea and inland navigation); energy (nuclear plants, distribution and transfer systems of electricity, oil, gas); hazardous substances (chemical and biological agents, nuclear reactors); information and telecommunication technology; finance, currency and insurance (banks, insurance companies, financial service providers, stock markets); public utilities (health, emergency and rescue sector, disaster control, food and water supply, waste management); government, administration, justice, police, customs and armed forces.\nMany of these critical infrastructure systems are based on computer-based control systems, such as the generation and distribution of electricity or telecommunications. Some function entirely on the basis of an Internet connection, including the banking and stock exchange systems. Other areas are increasingly reliant on the Internet, for example the so-called e-justice and e-government. In any technologically highly developed, post-industrial State most of the critical infrastructure systems can be deemed to depend on the operability and efficiency of electronic data transfer. The devastating effects and the subsequent disruption of the ordre public caused by a CNA are limited only by the imagination of the reader. Therefore, cyber security plays a paramount role for the national security of many States and was noted as one of the major perils for the Alliance's security in NATO's Strategic Concept of 2010 (see supra I).\nThere is open source information available in the media on CNA being conducted during peacetime.\nThe only publicly known case, in which the attribution of a CNA to a particular State can be asserted, was the penetration and temporary disabling of Syrian air defence networks, especially the radar systems, by Israel on 6 September 2007, immediately followed by an airstrike by Israel's Air Force destroying Syria's Al Kibar nuclear reactor in Deir-Az-Zur.\n See the list of critical infrastructure systems, available at https://www.bsi.bund.de/cln_183/ContentBSI/Publikationen/Faltblaetter/F17KritischeInfrastruktur.html.\n Ben-David, supra note 8.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nA more prominent case of a successful CNA against a State are the DDoS-attacks launched against several critical infrastructure systems in Estonia during the 27 April – 18 May 2007 timeframe. The “attacks” targeted websites and communication channels of the government and commercial services. For example, the web-services of the major banks Hansapank and SEB Eesti Ühispank were (at one-time) interrupted for 1,5 hours; the website of a governing coalition party was defaced; emergency phone numbers were disengaged for a short time; and three major Estonian Internet Service Providers and some online news providers were disconnected (although it is unclear for how long). The estimated physical (because of the disengagement of emergency phone numbers) and economic damage caused by the DDoS-attacks remains unclear. The attacks most probably originated from the territory of the Russian Federation. Given the relatively simple DDoS-methods and the political context of the relocation of a Soviet war memorial in Tallinn, it is asserted that the “attackers” were politically motivated private persons (hacktivism).\nAnother example of successful CNA during peacetime are the defacement and DDoS-attacks launched against Lithuania between 28 June and 1 July 2008. The CNA may have been connected either to the amendment of Lithuania’s laws to prohibit the display of symbols of the Soviet Union or the singing of its anthem in public or to the unilateral veto against discussions on an EU energy partnership deal with Russian Federation. Over 300 Lithuanian websites were defaced, including those of the Government. Given the pro-Russian contents\n\nof the defacement, as well as the subject of the (unsolicited) spam emails “Hackers United against external threats to Russia”, the CNA is assumed to have originated with nationalistic, private hacker groups (hacktivism).42\nOn the contrary, the “Conficker” worm, reported to have been created by Russian criminals, was not aimed at State structures, as it spread worldwide, affecting both private and official networks. It did gain national interest of the victim States, when it began to affect governmental and military computer systems, including those of the British Parliament,43 and the French and British air forces and navies.44\nThe worm “Stuxnet”, which affected over 100.000 computer systems worldwide between June and September 2010, targeted industrial control systems of gas pipelines and power plants based on Siemens software, aiming to establish remote control of the systems and to hide any changes in the computer systems from the operators of the equipment.45 As the vast majority of the infections affected Iran’s critical infrastructure systems, in particular of the nuclear power plant near Bushehr, and the worm’s reach and complexity obviously required enormous personnel and budgetary investments as well as a considerable amount of time to write the code (in secrecy), the involvement of a foreign organization or State is suspected.46\n\nAlthough there is no respective open source information, it must be assumed that, in the past, CNA were also successfully launched against NATO’s computer systems. The *Analysis and Recommendations of the Group of Experts on a New Strategic Concept for NATO* presented on 17 May 2010 noted: “Already, cyber attacks against NATO systems occur frequently, but most often below the threshold of political concern”.\nFurthermore, CNA were conducted during times of armed conflict, as for example during *Operation Allied Force* (24 March – 10 June 1999) launched by 10 NATO Member States against Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. At the beginning of the operation, websites and the mailing system of NATO were blocked and infected by a virus (Melissa), apparently originating in Serbia. Furthermore, some defacement attacks were launched by politically motivated individuals (hacktivism) from Serbia and Russia (*Black Hand, From Russia with Love, Russian Hacker Union*, etc.) against websites of NATO and NATO Member States. Equally, some hackers groups (politically) supporting the NATO operation (e.g. *Dutchthreat* or *Kosovo Hackers Group*) tried to infiltrate the governmental websites of Yugoslavia. Moreover, it is suspected that the President of the USA, *Bill Clinton*, did authorize the *Central Intelligence Agency* (CIA) to penetrate the computer systems of banks in Greece, Lebanon, Russia and Cyprus in order to clear the banking accounts of the President of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia *Slobodan Milošević*. Those were DDoS-attacks and defacements mainly directed against Georgian government websites but also the web portals of Georgia’s National Bank and news agencies, partly resulting in shutting down the website servers for hours or days. Although suspicions of the – officially disclaimed – involvement of the Russian Federation in the cyber incidents remain, these incidences were allegedly attributed to the criminal organization “Russian Business Network” (hosting and renting illegal web services).\nIn regard to the aforementioned armed conflicts, it can be inferred that the conduct of CNO did partly influence the perception of the conflict in the public, but not its overall outcome. It can be assumed that also in the near future CNO are very likely to be used merely in support of a conventional military operation, mainly military intelligence, reconnaissance and surveillance, or in order to influence the perception of a particular political conflict in the online media.\n## 2. Identification of the Origin and Attribution of Malicious CNO\nIt will always be difficult to unequivocally identify the computer systems that malicious CNO originated from and to attribute the attack to a certain entity, group or a State.\nA cyber attack is distinguished by its rapidness. As soon as the attack is completed, the tracing of the data stream (so-called back-tracing) and\nnews.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/352059.stm; ‘CIA Ordered to Topple Milosevic’, BBC News online of 6 July 1999, available at http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/387463. stm; and F. Rötzer, ‘CIA im Crackerkrieg gegen Milosevich?’, heise online of 24 May 1999, available at http://www.heise.de/tp/r4/artikel/2/2874/1.html.\n Id.\n See Independent International Fact-Finding Mission on the Conflict in Georgia, Report (September 2009), Vol. II., pp. 217 et seq., available at http://www.ceig.ch/pdf/IIFFMCG_Volume_II.pdf; and J. Markoff, ‘Before the Gunfire, Cyberattacks’, The New York Times online of 13 August 2008, available at http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/13/technology/13cyber.html?_r=2&amp;em.\n For more details, see id.\n Id.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nthus the identification of the originating computer system are highly improbable. It is highly unlikely that hackers will leave any tangible evidence, for example in the protocols of the intrusion detection systems of the attacked network, as such evidence in these protocols is easy to delete once the network is penetrated.\nMoreover, and further aggravating the issue, a cyber-attack can be conducted “anonymously”, for example by using one of the (often) free of charge anonymisation services offered on the Internet which would hide the unique characteristics of the hackers’ computer system. These unique characteristics are the so-called IP address as well as other technical data a computer sends while connected to the Internet.\n An IP address (Internet Protocol number) is a twelve digit number, which identifies a computer or another network device during an Internet session. An IP data package is the basic element of data transmission via the Internet. It comprises: a header (containing information on the source, destination, status and fragmentation of the transmitted data) and a payload (containing the transmitted data). At the very beginning of the Internet, the IANA (see supra note 1) assigned static IP addresses, i.e. IP addresses permanently assigned to a particular user, to companies, organizations, universities and also to individuals. The assignment of IP addresses to individual users or of IP address ranges to Internet Access Providers is now regulated by ICANN (see supra note 1). Since February 2005, ICANN delegates this task to five Regional Internet Registries (RIR), i.e. regional organisations assigning IP addresses. These are AfriNIC (Africa), APNIC (Asia and Pacific), ARIN (North America), LACNIC (Latin America and Caribbean Region) and RIPE NCC (Europe, Near East and Central Asia). The regional organisations assign the IP addresses to local organisations, mainly to Internet Service Providers (e.g. yahoo, gmail etc). Usually, an Internet user receives from the pool of IP addresses at the disposal of an Access Provider a specific (dynamic) IP address for the particular Internet session only. After the particular Internet session the dynamic IP address is assigned to another user and client of the respective Access Provider. At present, the so-called static IP-addresses are only being used for leased Internet-lines of major corporations and other entities.\n These include: Media Access Control address (MAC address) or – for the operating system Apple – the Airport ID of a computer (order of numbers, which clearly identifies a computer hardware); Address Resolution Protocol (ARP, details on the assignment of a MAC address or Airport ID to an IP address); Service Set Identity (SSID, details on the network name); Wired Equivalent Privacy Protocol (WEP, coded details about the network); as well as details on the operating system and its adjustments. These details are – if not blocked – automatically transferred during the Internet session to any computer requesting this information by a so-called PING (Packet InterNet Grouper). A PING is computer software sending an ICMP-Echo-Request data package to the destination address of the host which is to be scanned, i.e. to the IP address, to the Domain Name System name (DNS name) or to the Network Basic Input Output System name (NetBIOS name) of the targeted host. The targeted system automatically responds by an ICMP-Echo-Reply, if – according to the usual adjustments of the system – the system supports the ICMP package.\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\nFurthermore, the Internet offers possibilities for deception in regard to the identity of the hackers' computer systems. It is perfectly possible to feign someone else's IP address and other technical data (so-called malicious misrepresentation or spoofing) and thus to operate in the Internet under someone else's \"cyber-identity\". The connection to the Internet can also be established via a mobile phone or other device with a feigned identity number. Additionally, the data stream can be conducted through the whole globe via a chain of computers of numerous unsuspecting individuals, if so-called zombie software (partly offered free of charge on the Internet) has been secretly installed on the respective computers by using Trojans. One of these computers could subsequently be misused as the sender of the data stream (so-called remote control). Thus, in the case of a cyber attack, even after a back tracing of the malicious data stream, the victim can seldom be sure as of the identification and geographical location of the computer system the attack originated from.\nAbove all, even if a malicious data stream of a cyber attack would indeed be successfully back-traced to the hackers' computer systems, it will – highly probable – remain unproven which individuals of which citizenship and on who's orders were operating the systems identified. Therefore, the attribution of a cyber attack to a certain individual, group, entity or State will most probably be based on unproven suspicions or indications only.\nConsequently, it will be very unlikely to recognize at first sight – and probably even after detailed technical analysis – whether the attack was conducted by a mischievous teenager, by a criminal (including a terrorist), by a group with extremist or terrorist background or by the adversary Party in an armed conflict.\nThese uncertainties will surely add to the complexity of both the legal analysis of a cyber attack and the victim's decision on choosing a subsequent course of action. Considering the difficulty in identifying and locating the hackers' computer systems and – most importantly – attributing the attack, in most cases it will remain in doubt whether national police forces and public prosecutors or, in the framework of international judicial cooperation, the police forces and public prosecutors of a foreign State, or the armed forces (in the case the attack occurs during an already existing armed conflict and is believed to have originated with a party to the armed conflict, or in the case the effects of the cyber-attack are comparable to a conventional armed\n\nattack and trigger the right to self-defence) retain main responsibility to deal with the case.\n## 3. CNO in Modern Warfare\nThe significance of CNO for the conduct of military operations is manifold.\nWhilst most armed conflicts in this day and age are occurring in regions that are technologically less sophisticated (e.g. Afghanistan, Sudan or Chad), this does not result in the irrelevance of the Internet and of CNO. It must be taken into consideration that, in regard to communication abilities and collection of open source information, the parties to armed conflicts in less well developed regions are also essentially dependent on – aside from radio traffic – wireless Internet connectivity, as other communication and information systems (e.g. telecommunication media, print media, telephone lines) are often non-existent.\nIt is especially evident in the context of so-called asymmetric warfare and in the hands of non-state actors, for instance terrorists, that CNO can be a powerful weapon, primarily against post-industrial States and their potent armed forces. More than ever, post-industrial States have technologically highly developed armed forces at their disposal, which correspondingly react most sensitively to technical disorder. It is the dependence on the technology which makes them extremely vulnerable to a cyber attack.\nAs CNO can be conducted from any place in the world by as little as a few experts and, in addition, are extraordinarily inexpensive when compared with conventional military operations, they offer a particularly practical and extremely powerful \"weapon\". Therefore, all aspects of CNO (see supra II.1) show an increasing significance in the context of national as well as of international security.\nAs the Head of the NATO Computer Incident Response Capability Co-ordination Centre stated already in 2008: \"Cyber war can become a very effective global problem because it is low-risk, low-cost, highly effective and easily globally deployable. It is almost an ideal weapon that nobody can ignore\".60\n\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\n## III. Legal Analysis of CNO\nAlthough some scholars plead for a general prohibition of CNO, currently such a ban does not exist. However, many international and domestic legal restrictions do apply to CNO – a fact which makes a legal analysis a complex undertaking.\nApart from the fundamental principle of public international law, namely the prohibition of the threat or use of force in international relations, a number of specific areas of public international law may apply to CNO. As data packages pass through the territory of several States when sent via the Internet, the provisions of territorial sovereignty must be considered. Also, data manipulations might – under certain circumstances – be judged as intervention in domestic affairs of a State, which would be considered illegal under public international law. Further, because satellite technology is involved, space law and especially treaties relating to satellites must be considered. As CNO can interfere with telecommunication systems and always result in data amendments in the working storage of the attacked computer system, both international telecommunications law and international copyright law (in regard to software) require a thorough analysis. In case human rights treaty law is generally applicable, their respective provisions must be considered, especially in regard to secrecy of correspondence, telecommunications and data protection, as well as to the right to receive and impart information and ideas. Restraints for CNO can further result from the provisions of diplomatic and consular law, whenever diplomatic or consular computer systems are involved. Furthermore, it has been asserted that international environmental law principles of good neighbourhood and of the prevention of significant trans-boundary harm would be applicable to CNO in analogy. In addition, the provisions of\n A. D’Amato pleads for a general prohibition of CNO, emphasizing that the stability of the international community depends on the free flow of information (p. 68) and that every nation has a vital interest in the operationability of the Internet (p. 69), see A. D’Amato, ‘International Law, Cybernetics, and Cyberspace’, in M.N. Schmitt &amp; B.T. O’Donnell (eds.), *Computer Network Attack and International Law* (Newport / Rhode Island, US Naval War College, 2002), pp. 59–71, pp. 67–69. See also: T. Morth, ‘Considering Our Position. Viewing Information Warfare as Use of Force Prohibited by Article 2(4) of the U.N. Charter’, Vol. 30 *Case Western Reserve* J.I.L. 1998, p. 600.\n Such assertion is made – emphasizing that the Internet is a global resource comparable to the natural environment – by T. Stein &amp; T. Marauhn, ‘Völkerrechtliche Aspekte von Informationsoperationen’, Vol. 60 *Zeitschrift für ausländisches öffentliches Recht und Völkerrecht* 2000, p. 21. A similar approach\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nrespective national law systems, especially constitutional and criminal law, must always be taken into consideration.\nGiven the variety of areas of law involved and the limited scope of this survey, the following remarks will be restricted to the analysis of LOAC, focusing on the provisions of the Regulations concerning the Laws and Customs of War on Land, Annex to the Hague Convention (IV) respecting the Laws and Customs of War on Land of 18 October 1907 (HR), the four Geneva Conventions of 1949 (GC) $^{63}$ and their Additional Protocols I $^{64}$ (AP I) and II $^{65}$ (AP II) (2). However, first of all, it must be examined under which conditions LOAC applies to CNO (1).\n## 1. The Applicability of the Laws of Armed Conflict\nAccording to common Article 2 of the GCs, LOAC applies to\nall cases of declared war or of any other armed conflict which may arise between two or more of the High Contracting Parties, even if the state of war is not recognized by one of them. The Convention shall also apply to all cases of partial or total occupation of the territory of a High Contracting Party, even if the said occupation meets with no armed resistance.\nIn practice, armed conflicts surely can be considered as the main case of application of LOAC. Pursuant to the prevailing opinion an\nis taken by the (non-binding) OECD Guidelines for the Security of Information Systems of 1992, which call for cooperation of States (Principle 6) in the area of comprehensive protection of information systems (Principle 4), and which stipulate an imperative of deliberation in the use of information systems (Principle 3), see OECD Doc. OCDE/GD(92)190. However, an analogous application of international environmental law provisions is not convincing because of the lack of an “unintended omission” or of the absence of regulation. International telecommunication law, in particular the provisions of the (almost universally ratified) Constitution of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) of 22 December 1992, binds ITU Member States to far-reaching obligations in regard to the protection of communication and information systems (see in particular Articles 6, 33, 38, 45 and 47 of the ITU Constitution).\n$^{63}$ These are: Convention (I) for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded and Sick in Armed Forces in the Field of 12 August 1949; Convention (II) for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded, Sick and Shipwrecked Members of Armed Forces at Sea of 12 August 1949; Convention (III) Relative to the Treatment of Prisoners of War of 12 August 1949; Convention (IV) Relative to the Protection of Civilian Persons in Time of War of 12 August 1949.\n$^{64}$ Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949, and Relating to the Protection of Victims of International Armed Conflicts (Protocol I) of 8 June 1977 (entered into force on 7 December 1978).\n$^{65}$ Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949, and Relating to the Protection of Victims of Non-International Armed Conflicts (Protocol II) of 8 June 1977 (entered into force on 7 December 1978).\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\ninternational armed conflict occurs when one or more States have recourse to “armed force” against another State, regardless of the legality, reasons or the intensity of this confrontation. This opinion is confirmed by the Commentary on the GC which states that “any difference arising between two States and leading to the intervention of armed forces is an armed conflict within the meaning of Article 2”. Art. 1(4) AP I extends the definition of international armed conflict to include armed conflicts in which peoples are fighting against colonial domination, alien occupation or racist regimes in the exercise of their right to self-determination. A non-international armed conflict within the meaning of the common Article 3 GCs occurs when one or more non-governmental organized armed groups are involved and the situation reaches a certain threshold of confrontation, distinguishing it from internal disturbances, riots or acts of banditry (see also Art. 1 AP II). Thus, a situation of an (international or non-international) armed conflict and consequently the application of LOAC is given, when States or – under certain circumstances – organized armed groups use “armed force” against the other Party.\nUnsurprisingly, LOAC is applicable to all CNO conducted either in support of conventional military operations carried out in the event of an already ongoing armed conflict or conducted as the first step preparing the immediate start of conventional military operations altogether comprising an armed conflict.\nWhether “cyber war”, i.e. military operations conducted exclusively by the means of the Internet or other computer networks without the employment of other weaponry (in the following referred to as: “isolated” CNO), will ever per se be classified as “use of armed force” and thus comprise an armed conflict, depends on future State practice. As there is an absence of detailed academic work on this particular\n See D. Fleck (ed.), *The Handbook of International Humanitarian Law* (Oxford / New York, Oxford University Press, 2008, 2nd ed.), §§ 202 and 210; see also a compendium of scholar opinions in: International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), *How is the Term “Armed Conflict” Defined in International Humanitarian Law?*, Opinion Paper (March 2008), p. 1 et seq., available at http://www.icrc.org/eng/assets/files/other/opinion-paper-armed-conflict.pdf.\n J. Pictet, *Commentary on the Geneva Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded and Sick in Armed Forces in the Field* (Geneva, ICRC, 1952), p. 32.\n See ICRC, *supra* note 66, p. 2.\n *Id.*\n E.g. J.P. Terry describes cyberwar as a “lesser form of international conflict”, see J.P. Terry, ‘Responding to Attacks on Critical Computer Infrastructure. What\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nquestion, the following remarks will show criteria useful for the assessment whether particular types of “isolated” CNO constitute an armed conflict (A.). Furthermore, it will be analysed how the ius in bello terms “attack”, “act of violence” and “hostilities” apply to CNO (B.).\n## A. “Isolated” CNO as Armed Conflict\nAs stated above, an (international or non-international) armed conflict occurs when States or – under certain circumstances – (a State and/or) organized armed group(s) use “armed force” against each other.\nOf course, the notion of “use of armed force” – indicating that differences and confrontations did indeed reach the threshold of an (international or non-international) armed conflict and thus trigger the applicability of the ius in bello – is to be distinguished from the term “use of (armed)” force pursuant to Article 2(4) UN Charter, although the two terms are closely related. Whenever a State conducts actions considered as a “use of armed force” in the meaning of ius ad bellum against another State, this indicates the outbreak of hostilities reaching the level of “use of force” in the meaning of ius in bello and thus the threshold of an armed conflict triggering the applicability of LOAC – with the possible exception of quick, discrete and “surgical” use of force in the meaning of Article 2(4) UN Charter without further retort by the victim (as e.g. the bombardment of the Iraqi nuclear reactor in Osirak/Iraq by Israeli Air Force in 1981).\nIn the following, criteria for the assessment whether a particular type of “isolated” CNO constitutes an armed conflict will be developed. The question whether a certain type of CNO can be deemed as “use of armed\nTargets? What Rules of Engagement?”, in Schmitt &amp; O'Donnell, supra note 61, p. 434; see also the remarks by L. Doswald-Beck, 'Some Thoughts on Computer Network Attack and the International Law of Armed Conflict', in Schmitt &amp; O'Donnell, supra note 61, p. 165.\n\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\nforce” (in the *ius in bello* meaning) will be examined (while – apart from the above stated exception – exactly the same criteria can indicate whether “use of force” in the meaning of the *ius ad bellum* is given). However, most academic writings on CNO do refer to “use of armed force” in the meaning of Article 2(4) UN Charter. References to such writings will be made when useful and appropriate in the discussion of the term “use of armed force” in the *ius in bello* meaning.\nAccording to the traditional understanding, the assumption is that the “use of armed force” requires the employment of kinetic weaponry; that is the employment of a tool designed to cause kinetic effects of physical nature on a body or on an object. CNO are usually neither designed nor intended to directly cause kinetic effects. The transfer of data and its delay or interruption, as well as the manipulation, suppression or deletion of data cannot be deemed to cause kinetic effects in the common meaning of the term. Therefore, a significant qualitative difference between CNO and conventional weapons can be identified. In contrast, some similarities between CNO and biological or chemical weapons (hereinafter referred to as BC weapons) can be conceived. The use of BC weapons does not cause destruction in conventional sense, because these weapons do not set free any kinetic energy.72 The employment of BC weapons is considered as a form of “use of armed force” because, although not resulting in physical destruction of material, these weapons are employed in order to cause death or injury to living things.73 Thus, in the case of BC weapons, the term “weapon” is defined with reference to their effects rather than their method, which perfectly corresponds with the effects-based approach inherent to public international law. Consequently, the majority of scholars rightly insist on an effects-based interpretation of the term of “use of armed force” in the context of CNO.74\nTherefore, in the following, different categories of potential effects which can be caused by CNO will be illustrated in order to determine when CNO must be deemed as “use of armed force”.\n\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\ni. Death, Physical Injury and/or Destruction of Property\nAccording to the nearly uniform opinion among scholars (to which the author of the present survey subscribes), a CNO – similarly to the effects caused by BC weapons – should be considered as “use of armed force” if it results in death, physical injury or the destruction of property.75 As illustrated above (II.1.C), CNO can indirectly76 cause such effects.\nAccording to a minority view amongst scholars, a CNO, even if it indirectly causes death, physical injury or the destruction of property, qualifies as “use of armed force” only if at the same time it amounts to a “use of structural force”.77 “Structural force” is described in the public international law literature as a physical incursion into a State’s\n\nM.N. Schmitt proposes a catalogue of criteria indicating that CNO constitute “use of force”:\n- severity of the effects, i.e. threat of physical injury or destruction of property,\n- immediacy of the occurrence of the negative consequences,\n- direct nexus between the CNO and the negative consequences caused,\n- invasiveness of the consequences on foreign territory,\n- measurability of the consequences,\n- pre-assumption of illegitimacy of the CNO according to national rules and to the International Public Law, based on the prima facie illegitimacy of the use of force in international relations (the author of the present survey only guesses that the term “illegitimacy” indeed stands for “illegality”).\nSee Schmitt, supra note 28, pp. 65 et seq. This approach is not convincing because of the circular reasoning it contains. It cannot be decided whether a particular act is indeed illegal, by the simultaneous assertion of the illegality of the same act.\n\nterritory without the employment of conventional or mass destruction weapons, leaving the attacked State the “use of armed force” as the only option open for effective self-defence (e.g. in the case of intentional spreading of fire across a border, cutting the water supply, or causing widespread flooding).78 Thus, “structural force” is deemed as “use of armed force” in the sense of Article 2 (4) UN Charter if it has the same effect as an “armed attack” triggering the right to self-defence pursuant to Article 51 UN Charter.79 However, it must be considered that there is a significant qualitative difference between “use of armed force” and an “armed attack”. According to the prevailing opinion among public international law scholars and the settled jurisprudence of the International Court of Justice, an “armed attack” only occurs when the “use of armed force” reaches a certain level of intensity in regard to its effects and scale.80 When this threshold of intensity is not reached, the respective actions in question can still be considered as “use of armed force”, although they do not constitute an “armed attack”.81 Therefore, the above presented view asserting that CNO can only be deemed as “use of force” when it comprises “structural force”, and thus setting the terms of “use of armed force” and “armed attack” equal, is highly questionable.\nFurthermore, some scholars demand additional criteria to be met in order to classify CNO as “use of armed force”. This is the direct nexus between the CNO and physical damage, the immediacy of the occurrence of the physical damage (in the sense that the occurrence of the damage does not depend on any additional factors) as well as whether the damage can be foreseen at all.82 However, these criteria determine the conditions of attribution of the damage to a certain action, and are therefore not relevant for the specification of the term “use of armed force”.\n\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\n## ii. Destruction of Data\nSome academic writings assert that the destruction of data of substantial importance and/or of significant economical value should be considered as “use of armed force”.83 But, in consequence, it would need to have been ascertained in every particular case whether indeed data of some economic value has been destroyed or whether the CNO is to be considered as trivial because the compromised or deleted data is of little or no value. In addition, it must be considered that in the case of a so-called DoS attack84 data will not be destroyed but rather its use and information value will be diminished by delay of its transmission or by temporary denial of access to the data. Furthermore, the effect of CNO directed against data only is not comparable to the effects of conventional weapons, for example a bombardment, or of BC weapons. Therefore, the above presented view is not convincing, as it is of little practical value and could lead to unbearable results.\nOther scholars assert that at least the destruction of data symbolizing an asset (e.g. data of an electronically operated banking account) should be considered as “use of armed force”.85 They suggest that this assessment would reflect the obligation to protect civilian objects from dangers arising from military operations.86 However, electronic assets, accounts, demands or claims cannot be equated with objects or physical property and their destruction cannot be compared with the destructive effects on physical property caused by conventional (or BC) weapons. Therefore, the opinion presented above does not capture accurately the translation of the traditional understanding of the term “use of armed force” into the “cyberspace”.\nIf, however, a CNO was to be directed against the whole economic or banking system as one of the critical infrastructures of a State, the situation must be judged differently (see III.1.A.v. on critical infrastructure systems).\n## iii. “Theft” of Data\nMoreover, it is asserted that the “theft” of particular data should be considered as “use of armed force”, if information of vital interest to\n\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\na State, for instance classified information, is compromised. Also the “theft” of all data of military nature (regardless of the classification) should be considered as “use of armed force”. However, the “theft” of data (CNE) merely represents a kind of modern espionage which is not generally forbidden under public international law. All in all, “theft” of data – even classified data of importance to the military – cannot be deemed as having similar effects as conventional or BC weapons and therefore cannot be judged as “use of armed force”. Therefore, it is not convincing to view the “theft” of data as comprising an armed conflict.\niv. Massive Disruption of Military C3-Systems\nAdditionally, some scholars assert that the destruction or medium to long-term disruption of military command, control and communication systems (C3-systems) is to be deemed as “use of armed force”. Indeed, the intended outcome, namely the disruption of military communications and the consequent restraining ability on military command and control, can be achieved both through the physical destruction of respective systems by conventional weapons and through the massive disruption of the systems by malicious CNO. As such, the effect of a corresponding CNO is quite comparable to the effects of the employment of conventional weapons. This view is supported by Article VI of the Agreement on the Prevention of Dangerous Military Activities concluded between the USA and the Soviet Union on 12 June 1989. According to this provision, the disruption of command and control systems (C2), resulting even in a mere restraint of those systems, would be regarded as a dangerous military activity. Given the political context of the agreement the provision indicates that a – massive – disruption of\n Joyner &amp; Lotrione, supra note 75, pp. 846, 855; contra: Stein &amp; Marauhn, supra note 62, p. 10.\n Joyner &amp; Lotrione, supra note 75, pp. 846 and 856.\n D’Amato, supra note 61, p. 67; and Stein &amp; Marauhn, supra note 62, p. 32 with further references. In regard to CNO as a modern form of espionage see: von Heinegg, supra note 77, p. 134. Apart from the penalisation of espionage resulting from respective national law systems, spying is restrained by certain provisions of public international law, e.g. the taboos stated by the diplomatic and consular law protecting diplomatic and consular archives and correspondence, i.e. respective electronic databases and communication via the Internet.\n See M. Bothe, ‘Völkerrechtliche Verhinderung von Gewalt (ius contra bellum)’, in W. Graf Vitzthum, Völkerrecht (Berlin, De Gruyter, 2001), Section 8, § 10.\n Stein &amp; Marauhn, supra note 62, p. 8. See also Sharp, supra note 75, p. 129, who recognizes the right to self-defence against an attack on computer networks of “vital interest” to a State.\n Vol. 28 I.L.M. 1989, pp. 877 et seq.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nmilitary C3-systems could indeed be seen by States as “use of force”.\n## v. Massive Disruption of Critical Infrastructure Systems\nThere is still no uniform opinion among scholars whether massive disruption of critical infrastructure systems by means of CNO should be judged as “use of armed force”, if physical effects cannot be identified outside of the targeted computer systems. Partly, it is asserted that the disruption of critical infrastructure systems cannot at all be classified as “use of armed force”, because Article 41 UN Charter would consider the “[...] complete or partial interruption of economic relations and of rail, sea, air, postal, telegraphic, radio, and other means of communication [...]” as measures employed by the UN Security Council “[...] not involving the use of armed force [...]” This conclusion is not convincing as the disruption of the above mentioned systems can be caused either by measures not involving or by measures which do involve the “use of armed force”, whereas the latter find their legal basis in Article 42 UN Charter instead of Article 41.\nHowever, it is agreed amongst scholars that the effects of a massive disruption of critical infrastructure systems must exceed the threshold of merely minimally affecting the population’s quality of life or must go beyond a mere inconvenience, and must further show effects of disruption of the public life and *ordre public* similar to a bombardment. This way the effect of a corresponding CNO would indeed be comparable to the effect of the employment of conventional weapons.\nConsequently, the assertion can be made that not only the physical destruction but also the disruption of computer networks supporting critical infrastructure systems by means of CNO should be considered as “use of armed force”, provided that the disruption caused can be equated to destruction, i.e. resulting in medium to long-term disruption of the respective systems. It shall be only mentioned that there is no need to develop practical criteria for the decision when a respective CNO is to be regarded as “use of armed force” as the criteria will perfectly resemble the ones used to identify whether conventional military actions causing\n See supra section II.1.C.\n Schmitt, supra note 74, p. 912.\n Stein &amp; Marauhn, supra note 62, p. 7.\n Terry, supra note 69, pp. 428 et seq.; and Morth, supra note 61, p. 599. See also Sharp, supra note 75, pp. 129 et seq. Contra: Dinstein, supra note 75, p. 105; and Stein &amp; Marauhn, supra note 62, p. 8, who demand the occurrence of physical damage outside the targeted computer networks in order to qualify CNO as use of force.\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\nsimilar effects on critical infrastructure systems would be considered as “use of armed force”.\nvi. Intermediate Result\nAll in all, only “isolated” CNO which cause deaths, physical injuries, destruction of property or the (medium to long-term) disruption of critical infrastructure systems of a State can be considered as “use of armed force” and thus constitute an armed conflict.\nB. Malicious CNO as “Attacks”, “Acts of Violence” or “Hostilities”\nAs far as LOAC provisions refer to “attacks”97, “acts of violence”98 or “hostilities”99 it can be asserted that they apply to malicious CNO which are to be considered as “use of armed force”. Consequently, a CNO could be considered as an “attack” (in the meaning of ius in bello), an “act of violence” or as “hostilities” if it – indirectly – caused death, physical injury, destruction of property or the (medium to long-term) disruption of critical infrastructure systems of a State.\n2. Restraints for Malicious CNO Resulting from LOAC Provisions\nIn the following, LOAC provisions, as reflected in the Hague Conventions, the universal100 Geneva Conventions and their Additional Protocols as well as other treaties, will be examined.\nThe Hague and Geneva Conventions entered into force long before the Internet era. The Additional Protocols entered into force in 1978, at a time when computers already existed, but the Internet in its present form and extent did not. Therefore, the textual analysis of the wording of relevant LOAC provisions covers the execution of malicious CNO only when the act referred to can also be committed by the use of the telecommunication means of the Internet, e.g. in regard to disseminating information, which contains threats of violence, the primary purpose of\n\nwhich is to spread terror among the civilian population, as prohibited in Article 51(2) AP I. Obviously, the systematic and historic interpretation of the treaties does not offer any further insight. However, the relevant provisions reveal surprising actuality, when a teleological interpretation of the rules is applied, i.e. the spirit and purpose of a particular provision is examined. In the following, this will be applied in regard to prohibitions in regard to methods and means of warfare (a) and lawful targets (b).\n## A. Prohibited Methods and Means of Warfare\n### i. Perfidy\nArticle 23(f) HR in conjunction with Articles 38 and 39 AP I as well as Article 12 AP II prohibit the misuse of distinctive emblems, signs, signals or flags of protected entities, including those of the Red Cross and its associated entities and of the United Nations. Furthermore, the provisions ban the misuse of flags or military emblems, insignia or uniforms of neutral or other States not Party to the particular armed conflict as well as of the adversary Party (though, in regard to the latter only while engaging in attack or in order to shield, favour, protect or impede military operations). Moreover, Article 44(3) AP I states the obligation for all members of the armed forces to distinguish themselves from the civilian population while engaged in an attack or in a military operation preparatory to an attack.\nAlthough the above-mentioned provisions refer to physically visible symbols carried by individuals or objects, the rules can also be observed in the \"cyberspace\". The spirit and purpose of these provisions is to preserve the neutrality of certain entities and to protect certain groups against dangers arising from military operations. Therefore, Parties to an armed conflict must not misuse the identity of these entities or groups. Consequently, the \"cyber identity\" (i.e. website, e-mail address, email header, IP address and other technical data sent while connected to the Internet) of one of the protected organisations or groups must not be used at any time during the conduct of CNO. A simple example of the ban would be that the header of an e-mail sent to adversary armed forces, containing a virus, indirectly causing physical damage outside the targeted network, must not show, for instance, the Red Cross as the\n Also see the Annex I to the AP I.\n Exceptions to those rules are stated in Article 39(3) AP I in regard to espionage and to the conduct of armed conflict at sea.\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\nsender. Also, while hacking adversary computer networks, the CNO forces must not feign technical data, which would lead to presumption of the “cyber identity” of a civilian if the concrete CNO conducted is to be considered as an “attack” or an “act preparatory to an attack” in the meaning of Article 44(3) AP I. Moreover, any respective manipulation of websites belonging to the protected entities would be illegal.\nIn addition, the prohibition of Article 23(b) HR in conjunction with Article 37(1) AP I, to kill, injure or capture an adversary under recourse to perfidy, applies to CNO. In general terms, perfidy describes an act which leads the adversary to erroneously believe that he or she is entitled to, or is obliged to accord protection under LOAC (see the definition of perfidy in Article 37(1) AP I). The ban covers, inter alia, intentional dissemination of misinformation to the adversary Party about the intent to negotiate under a flag of truce or of a surrender, or about an incapacitation by wounds or sickness, as well as feigning civilian, non-combatant or protected status (e.g. of a United Nations employee or of a member of a neutral or other State not Party to the conflict, by using respective emblems, signs, signals or uniforms, see Art. 23(f) HR and Art. 37(1) AP I). The aforementioned misinformation can generally be transmitted by the means of the Internet, for example by e-mail or as a statement on a website. As already stated (e.g. supra II.2.), the “cyber-identity” of the aforementioned protected persons can easily be feigned in the “cyberspace”. However, the above described dissemination of misinformation or feigning of the (cyber) identity of a protected person is prohibited only if it directly results in the death, injury or capture of the adversary.\nConversely, legal ruses of war in the sense of Article 24 HR and Article 37(2) AP I, which are merely aimed to mislead an adversary or to induce him to act recklessly, offer a broad field of application to CNO. Thus, it is imaginable that a Party to an armed conflict establishes a so-called honey net around its own computer network, i.e. an outside-network building a buffer around its own computer network, which is only minimally protected against hacking and, technically speaking,\n The specific nexus between the dissemination of misinformation or feigning of a protected status on the one hand and the death, injury or capture of the adversary on the other hand is required in order to establish accountability of armed forces, as – in the traditional understanding of warfare – all military actions always pursue death, injury or capture of the adversary, see M. Bothe, K.J. Partsch &amp; W.A. Solf, *New Rules for Victims of Armed Conflicts. Commentary on the Two 1977 Protocols Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 1949* (The Hague / Boston / London, Martinus Nijhoff, 1982), Art. 37 (1) AP I, no. 2.4, p. 204.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nappears perfectly realistic, but contains false information, for example on planned military operations or on the status of own forces and their location. Such a honey net could be established specifically in the hope that the adversary Party would compromise it and – in this way – obtain false information.\n## ii. Methods or Means of Warfare Prohibited Because of the Nature of Their Effects\nSome methods or means of warfare are prohibited because of the nature of their effects.\nAccording to Article 51(2) AP I and Article 13(2) AP II, acts or threats of violence, the primary purpose of which is to spread terror among the civilian population, are prohibited. This ban refers to the dissemination of certain information to the civilian population. As this information could be easily transmitted by means of computer-based information systems, for example via e-mail or as information on a website, this prohibition must be considered during the planning and the conduct of CNO.\nFurthermore, Article 23(e) HR, Article 35(2) AP I, the Convention on Prohibitions or Restrictions on the Use of Certain Conventional Weapons Which May be Deemed to be Excessively Injurious or to Have Indiscriminate Effects of 1980 and its Protocols as well as the Convention on Cluster Munitions of 2008 prohibit the employment of methods or means of warfare of a nature to cause superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering. Equally, Articles 51(5)(b) and 57(2)(a)(iii) AP I stipulate that an attack which may be expected to cause loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects or a combination of these, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated, is prohibited. As it is perfectly possible that a cyber attack could indirectly cause physical damage (see supra II.1.C), it must be examined beforehand whether the anticipated (indirect) effect would be excessive in the sense of the above-mentioned provisions. In this regard, as the expected effects of concrete CNO\n Those are: Protocol on Non-Detectable Fragments (Protocol I) of 1980, Protocol on Prohibitions or Restrictions on the Use of Mines, Booby-Traps and Other Devices (Protocol II) of 1980, Protocol on Prohibitions or Restrictions on the Use of Incendiary Weapons (Protocol III) of 1980, Protocol on Blinding Laser Weapons (Protocol IV) of 1995, and Protocol on Explosive Remnants of War (Protocol V) of 2003.\n See E.T. Jensen, ‘Unexpected Consequences from Knock-Out Effects: A Different\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\nare to be assessed, the practical criteria for the examination resemble to ones for the analysis of the effects caused by other (e.g. conventional) weapons.\nMoreover, according to Article 51(4) AP I indiscriminate attacks are prohibited. Attacks are deemed to be indiscriminate, when they are not or cannot be directed at a specific military objective, or when their effects cannot be limited (see Art. 51(4)(a)-(c) AP I). It is perfectly possible that CNO equated to an “attack” (in the meaning of ius in bello) or an “act of violence” (see III.1.B.) could have indiscriminate effects, in the case of global, uncontrolled spreading of viruses, bugs and – in future – micro-mechanical organisms via the Internet. However, damaging software could be programmed in such a way so as to only target computer systems with specific IP addresses or IP address ranges. An uncontrolled spread of malware, as well as any cascade effects, could be easily prevented by appropriate programming.\nHowever, the vast majority of malicious CNO will not achieve the quality of a “method or means of combat, the effects of which are indiscriminate”. The inductive conclusion drawn from the examples given by Articles 51(4)(a) and (b) AP I shows that the provisions refer to methods or means of combat which result in physically “devastating” physical effects.\nFinally, Article 35(3) in connection with Article 55(1) AP I prohibits the employment of methods or means of warfare which may be expected to cause widespread, long-term and severe damage to the natural environment. This provision covers only especially extensive, intensive and long-lasting environmental damage, which exceeds the scale of both the quality and quantity of “ordinary” environmental damage which is expected to occur in the course of combat.[108] Severe damage of the natural environment can always be caused when dangerous forces are set free, such as by radiation escaping from a nuclear power plant, the explosion of a chemical or pharmacy installation, or the breaking of a dam or dyke. As such effects could be caused indirectly by CNO\nStandard for Computer Network Operations?', Vol. 18 American University LL.Rev. 2003, pp. 1178 et seq.; and Schmitt, supra note 28, p. 82.\n\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\n(see supra II.1.C), the prohibition of Article 35(3) AP I must be also considered for operations primarily conducted within “cyberspace”.\n## B. Prohibited Targets\nFurthermore, LOAC provisions granting protection for non-combatants and for civilian objects are of significance for CNO.\n### i. Civilians Population and Individual Civilians\nThe civilian population as a whole, as well as individual civilians (see Art. 50 AP I), are protected against “attacks”, “acts of violence” and “effects of hostilities”. Accordingly, CNO which are not deemed as being “use of force”, and thus not comprising an “attack” (in the meaning of *ius in bello*), “act of violence” or “effect of hostilities” (see supra III.1.B) would not be contrary to LOAC and – from the perspective of international humanitarian law – could legally be directed against civilians.\nConversely, CNO considered as being a “use of force” could only be directed against civilians launching malicious CNO against the armed forces constituting “direct participation in hostilities” within the meaning of Article 51(3) AP I and Article 13(3) AP II. In order to distinguish between private hacking as “direct participation in hostilities” and hacking as a mere criminal act, all circumstances of a specific case must be taken into consideration (see also supra II.2).\nFurthermore, according to Article 48 AP I, the Parties to an armed conflict must, at all times, distinguish between the civilian population\n See e.g. Articles 49(1), 51, 52(1) and 54(2) AP I and Articles 11(1), 13 (2), 14 and 15 AP II.\n See e.g. Articles 49(1) and 50(2) AP I and Art. 13(2) AP II.\n See e.g. Articles 43(2), 44(3), 45, 49(4) and 51(3) AP I and Articles 4(1)(3) and 13(3) AP II.\n Concurring: Schmitt, supra note 106, p. 378.\n The examination of the different approaches to the question of the direct participation of civilians in hostilities, and especially of the temporal scope of the loss of protection otherwise granted by international humanitarian law, would certainly exceed the scope of this survey. For further examination, the following literature may be recommended selectively: N. Melzer, *Interpretative Guidance on the Notion of Direct Participation in Hostilities* (Geneva, ICRC, May 2009), available at www.icrc.org; Bothe, Partsch &amp; Solf, supra note 103, Art. 51 AP I, no. 2.4.2.2., p. 303; M.N. Schmitt, ‘Direct Participation in Hostilities and 21st Century Armed Conflict’, in H. Fischer, U. Froissart, W.H. von Heinegg &amp; C. Raap (Hrsg.), *Krisensicherung und humanitärer Schutz – Crisis Management and Humanitarian Protection. Festschrift für Dieter Fleck* (Berlin, Berliner Wissenschafts-Verlag, 2004), pp. 505–529.\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\nand combatants. Admittedly, the conventional (visual) criteria for the identification of a combatant as set out in Articles 43 and 44 AP I are not helpful for CNO, during which the acting individuals are not physically visible. However, the obligation to distinguish can also be met within “cyberspace”. In the “virtual world”, a computer of a combatant can be distinguished from the computer of a non-combatant according to its IP address and other technical data automatically sent during an Internet session. It can easily be verified by everybody in one of the official WhoIs? Internet databases to which person or entity a specific IP address or an IP address range is assigned. In addition, the “owner” and the responsible administrators of websites can be found in the WhoIs? databases. Thus, in principle it can be confirmed whether a particular actor in the “virtual world” should be considered as a member of the armed forces or as a civilian.\nNevertheless, some challenges as to the identification of a person acting in the “cyberspace” as a combatant will remain. For example, a member of regular armed forces and thus a combatant will not be recognizable as such when using his private computer at home, the latter sending during an Internet session information identifying the user as a civilian. This resembles the “real world” situation, when a soldier is not wearing the uniform when being at home and thus cannot visually be identified as a combatant as well. Thus, the remaining challenges are not new and will mostly resemble similar “real world” cases.\n## ii. Civilian Objects\nAccording to Article 48 AP I, civilian objects must be distinguished from military objectives. Civilian objects must not be the objects of attack or reprisals (Articles 48, 52(1)-(2) and 57 AP I, see also Art. 23(g) HR and further specific regulations in Articles 53–56 AP I and Articles 14–16 AP II). Generally, this principle of distinction, as well as the above-mentioned prohibitions, can also be observed within the “virtual world”.\n See the profound examination by S. Watts, ‘Combatant Status and Computer Network Attack’, Vol. 50 No. 2 Virginia J.I.L. 2010, pp. 391–447.\n The WhoIs? databases of the RIRs (see supra note 58) provide information on which IP address is assigned to which end customer (in the case of dynamic IP-addresses: to which Internet Service Provider). Thus, the database DENIC (available at http://www.denic.de) provides respective information on “.de” domains, and the database RIPE (available at http://www.ripe.net) on the other domains in Europe, InterNIC (available at http://www.internic.net/whois.html) on the domains “com”, “edu”, “int”, “net” or “org”. The database Network Information Center (available at http://www.nic.com) leads to official and regional WhoIs? databases as well as to respective private databases available online.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nViruses, bugs and – in the future – micro-mechanical organisms can be programmed in such a way that they only affect military computer networks, namely those with corresponding IP addresses or IP address ranges. The identification of a computer or computer system as military or civilian can be made by a search request of a specific IP address in one of the Whols? databases (see supra III.2.B.i).\nMalicious CNO against a purely military computer network, such as the Intranet or other communication systems of armed forces supported by the Intranet, would be perfectly legal in regard to LOAC. CNO launched against civilian computer networks – in case they are not to be considered as military objectives pursuant to Article 52(2) AP I – would only be allowed when they are not to be considered as an “attack” in the sense of Article 49(1) AP I, i.e. would not cause any physical damage (see supra III.1.B). A mere suppression or denial of access of the civilian population to a computer network or to specific data as well as the mere manipulation or the deletion of particular data would not fall under the prohibition of attack, as long as physical damage in- or outside the directly affected networks is not caused. For example, the deletion of a particular electronically operated bank account of a civilian would not be forbidden as a matter of LOAC.\nDistinction between civilian objects and military objectives becomes difficult when a computer network is used by both combatants and non-combatants (so-called dual use objects). This applies especially to the global Internet where, apart from the civilian population, there is a high probability that it will also be used by Parties to an armed conflict for the purposes of communication and information gathering. According to some scholars, the Internet is to be deemed as a military objective as soon as it is also used for military purposes.[116] Considering that nowadays the Internet is as an equally important means of communication as telephone and telegraph connections were in the past, the aforementioned opinion is supported by the fact that the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) had already in 1956 classified the latter as military objectives.[117]\n[116] This assertion is made in general terms, referring to communication networks used for both military and civilian purposes by Jensen, supra note 105, pp. 1160 et seq.; J.P. Terry, ‘The Lawfulness of Attacking Computer Networks in Armed Conflict and in Self-Defense in Period Short of Armed Conflict: What are the Targeting Constrains?’, Vol. 169 Mil. L. Rev. 2001, p. 85; and Stein &amp; Marauhn, supra note 62, p. 35. Similarly: Bothe, Partsch &amp; Solf, supra note 103, Art. 52 AP I, no. 2.4.2., p. 324.\n[117] Annex Military Targets to the Draft Rules for the Limitation of Dangers Incurred\n\nHowever, some scholars refuse to classify civilian means of communication merely co-used for military purposes as a military objective. Indeed, in order to avoid any “automatism”, a thorough examination of the definition of a military objective provided by Article 52(2) AP I will be necessary. The definition clearly refers to objects only. Thus, at first sight, it seems doubtful whether the “virtual world” of the Internet can be deemed to be an object. However, the computer system Internet is not a purely intellectual construction. It comprises a multitude of objects, including technical equipment as servers, cables, cross points and access points; thus, the provision is in general applicable to the Internet. According to this definition, the computer system Internet or any other (dual use) computer network is to be considered as a military objective, if\n- the computer network makes an effective contribution to military action by its use, and\n- the total or partial destruction or neutralization of the computer network offered a definite (i.e. concrete and perceptible) military advantage (in regard to the overall military operation).\nWhether the Internet meets these conditions depends on the degree to which the other Party to the armed conflict uses the Internet, and whether this Party can easily revert to alternative communication means. Therefore, the characterisation of the Internet, or other dual use computer networks, as a military objective depends on the circumstances of the specific situation, especially on the degree of the dependence of the adversary Party on those networks, *ergo* on the level of the technologisation of the adversary armed forces.\nEven if the Internet was to be considered to be a military objective in the context of a particular armed conflict, it must be considered that it would be allowed to be attacked only as far as its physical elements\nby the Civilian Population in Time of War, see Fleck, supra note 66, § 443. von Heinegg, supra note 77, pp. 150 seq.\n The examination, whether the “contribution” shall have a particular significance for or shall merely support a certain military operation, would certainly exceed the scope of this survey. For further details see Fleck, supra note 66, § 442; and Bothe, Partsch &amp; Solf, supra note 103, Art. 52 AP I, § 2.4.3., p. 324.\n See R. Wedgwood, ‘Proportionality, Cyberwar and the Law of War’, in Schmitt &amp; O’Donnell, supra note 61, p. 225; and von Heinegg, supra note 77, p. 150.\n Wedgwood, supra note 120, p. 225; Heinegg, supra note 77, p. 149; Fleck, supra note 66, § 444; and Bothe, Partsch &amp; Solf, supra note 103, Art. 52 AP I, § 2.4.4. See also Art. 8(2)(b)(iv) of the ICC Statute.\n\n(e.g. server, cross points and WLAN access points) are located on the territory of one of the Parties to the particular armed conflict. But, even if such an attack was conducted successfully, a connection to the Internet could still be made from the same geographical area, for example via a mobile phone or other device enabled with respective software permitting Internet connectivity. Thus, an attack against the Internet intending the *quasi* disabling of a network within the area of conflict is unlikely to succeed.\n### iii. Objects under Special Protection\nAdditionally, LOAC provides special protection against attacks and reprisals for specific civilian objects. Corresponding prohibitions can be found in Article 27 HR, Articles 19-21 GC I., Articles 22 and 24 GC II., Articles 18 *et seq.* GC IV, Article 4 Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict of 1954 and in its Protocol I of 1954 and Protocol II of 1999, Articles 12, 21, 24 *et seq.*, 54(2) and (4) and 56 AP I as well as in Articles 11 and 14–16 AP II. Pursuant to these provisions, special protection is provided for dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations, objects indispensable to the survival of the civilian population (*inter alia* drinking water installations and water irrigation works), medical units and transportation, historic monuments, works of art or places of worship etc. As far as incorporating computer-based elements, the above-mentioned objects could be disrupted or even destroyed by the means of a cyber attack. Therefore, the computer-based cooling system of a nuclear power plant, for example, must not be disabled by remote control, a drinking water installation must not be destroyed by a computer controlled opening and closing of its valves, a medical aircraft must not be caused to crash by manipulation of data of an air traffic control system, or a museum protected by *ius in bello* must not be flooded by the remote activation of a water sprinkler system.\n In general terms, a *Wireless Local Area Network* (WLAN) describes a local wireless and direct connection between two or more mobile end devices (*clients*), which are equipped with a wireless access device. Usually, *clients* access the Internet via a central bridge (so-called *access point*). The bridge has a *router*, which – based on a *Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol* (DHPC server) – assigns a dynamic IP address to each *host* (see also *supra* note 58) seeking connectivity to the Internet.\n In order to disable the Internet, all its thirteen *root servers* (i.e. the main *domain name servers* or the main server layer of the internet) would have to be disconnected or destroyed. For security reasons, those servers are located in different, secret sites which are geographically distant. It is asserted that disabling up to ten of the *root servers* would probably merely delay the data transfer via the Internet.\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\nGenerally speaking, the aforementioned provisions, which provide special protection for specific civilian objects, can cease in the event that the objects are used to commit acts harmful to the enemy or for regular, significant and direct support for military operations of the enemy. In general terms, an active counter-CNO (back-hacking) could be legally launched once a warning has been given setting, whenever appropriate, a reasonable time-limit to stop the forbidden activities, and after such warning has remained unheeded. For example, in the case of the computer network of a medical unit, if it had been identified as the location of origin of malicious CNO, as an exception, an active counter-CNO could be launched if a warning about the forthcoming back-hacking had been given in advance, for instance in the form of a pop-up window which would appear on the computer screen of the cyber attacker.\nIt should also be considered that as far as an attack against an object is forbidden, the enemy must not be led to attack such objects. Therefore, CNO which would correspondingly manipulate a targeting database of the adversary Party to the armed conflict in order to assign the data of the geographical coordinates of a civilian object under special protection to the data of a military objective of the adversary Party would be forbidden. As an example, when manipulating the adversary's targeting database, a munitions factory must not be assigned the geographical coordinates of a hospital.\n## 3. The Law of Neutrality and the Cyberspace\nFirst of all, neutrality in the sense of *ius in bellum* has to be distinguished from permanent neutrality (e.g. the cases of Austria, the Holy See, and Switzerland), i.e. the legal obligation undertaken in peacetime to remain neutral in cases of armed conflict or war between other States, and from the mere neutrality policy (e.g. Finland, Sweden, Ireland), which, nonetheless, can have some legally binding effects due to the situation of confidence created in which other States may rely on the (political) declarations to remain neutral (principle of estoppel).\n## A. The Applicability of the Law of Neutrality\nNeutrality is a particular status of a State not Party to an armed conflict of significant scope or – according to a traditional view – to a “war\n Fleck, *supra* note 66, § 1105.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nin the legal sense” between other States. Although it is not crucial for the purposes of the present survey to decide which view is to be followed, it may be mentioned that the International Court of Justice stated in its Advisory Opinion on the *Legality of the Threat or Use of Nuclear Weapons* of 8 July 1996 that “[...] the principle of neutrality [...] is applicable [...], to all international armed conflict, whatever type of weapons might be used”.
