However, it must always be taken into consideration that in particular cases the rules governing neutrality may be modified by collective self-defence provisions such as Article 51 UN Charter and Article 5 North Atlantic Treaty (depriving a State of the possibility to legally join an armed conflict or a war on the side of the aggressor) and by (binding) decisions taken by the UN Security Council (see Articles 2(5) and 25 and Chapter VII UN Charter; the obligation to assist any action taken by the UN in accordance with the Charter would forestall a State to appeal to its neutrality).\nIn the following it will be shown that the rules on neutrality – which are over 100 years old – apply to military operations conducted in cyberspace (during an armed conflict of significant scope or a “war in the legal sense”). When examining the law of neutrality, no difference will be made between the specific rules applying to land, air or sea warfare, as the distinction between these areas is not relevant to CNO.\n## B. Prohibition of CNO Causing Physical Damage\nFirst and foremost, the rules of neutrality protect the territorial integrity and sovereignty of the neutral State, see Article 1 Hague Convention (V) respecting the Rights and Duties of Neutral Powers and Persons in Case of War on Land of 1907 (HC V) and Art. 1 Hague Convention (XIII) concerning the Rights and Duties of Neutral Powers in Naval War of 1907 (HC XIII).\nThus, the principle of neutrality prohibits causing physical damage on the sovereign territory of a neutral State. Consequently, a malicious\n The discussion of the question, whether rules on neutrality apply in situations of war (in legal sense) only or also in situations of an armed conflict of significant scope, would exceed the scope of the present survey. Interested readers may be referred to the assessment in Fleck, *supra* note 66, § 1106.\n ICI, *Legality of the Threat or Use of Nuclear Weapons*, Advisory Opinion of 8 July 1996, §§ 88–90 (emphasis by the author).\n See further details at Fleck, *supra* note 66, § 1103; and G. Walker, ‘Information Warfare and Neutrality’, Vol. 33 *Vanderbilt J. Transnational L.* 2000, pp. 1079 et seq.\n ICI, *Legality of the Threat or Use of Nuclear Weapons*, Advisory Opinion of 8 July 1996, §§ 88–90. Regarding the necessary criteria of a “physical encroachment”\n\nCNO would only breach the principle of the territorial inviolability of a neutral State if it – indirectly – caused physical damage (deaths, injuries or destruction of property) on the territory of a neutral State or medium to long-term disruption of critical infrastructure systems of a neutral State (see supra III.1.A.vi). In this regard, the physical damage could refer to physical components (technical equipment) of the Internet and/or other computer systems as well as to objects/living beings outside the affected computer systems.\nIn regard to critical infrastructure systems, it must always be considered that they can be shared by several States (e.g. an electricity distribution system is shared between Laos and Thailand, between Venezuela and Brazil, between Canada and the United States and between Indonesia and Singapore; one telecommunication system is shared by several States in East and South-East Asia).[129] Thus, before targeting a critical infrastructure system of the adversary it must always be examined (in addition to other LOAC provisions relevant to targeting) whether the estimated damage could also automatically affect another State neutral to the particular armed conflict or war.\n# C. The Use of Telecommunication Means Belonging to a Neutral State\nAccording to Article 8 HC V, a neutral State can allow the belligerents to use \"telegraph or telephone cables or of wireless telegraphy apparatus belonging to it or to companies or private individuals\". The neutral State also has the right to restrict or prohibit the use of such communication means, if applied (by the State, companies or individuals) impartially to all belligerents (see Article 9 HC V and 9(1) HC XIII).\nIn regard to the Internet, such a restriction or prohibition could be enforced by a neutral State by applying certain software to all Internet cross points located on its territory. The software would scan the Internet traffic for data packages sent by the belligerents and delete them. Of course, a neutral State could also disable all technical components supporting the worldwide network Internet and located on its territory. This way, the belligerents would not use the Internet components located on the territory of the neutral State, although the Internet system as such would continue to function and could be further used by the Parties to the armed conflict or war.\nsee Greenberg, Goodman &amp; Soo Hoo, supra note 75, p. 10.\n\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nIn the case one Party of the armed conflict or war used the computer network located on the territory of a neutral State to send malicious CNO to the computer systems of the other belligerent – either by launching malicious CNO from neutral State’s territory or by using Internet cross points or other technical equipment located on its territory –, the neutral State would have the right to “protect” its neutral status by taking appropriate actions (e.g. back-hacking). If it failed to do so, the neutral State would have – pursuant to the principle of non-discrimination of belligerents – the obligation to allow the affected belligerent to take action against the malicious CNO.^[130]^\n## D. Data Streams Passing the Territory of a Neutral State\nHowever, it is perfectly possible, even likely, that in the course of the conduct of CNO the data stream carrying malicious components (e.g. viruses or worms) to the adversary’s computer systems passes Internet crossing points and servers located on the territory of a neutral State. However, this would not result in violation of neutrality law.\nFirst of all, a Party to a conflict cannot influence whether a data stream crosses the technical components of the Internet situated on the territory of a neutral State or not. Every data stream sent via the Internet is divided in data packages, each one of which takes – out of millions possible routs – a certain route from cross point to cross point around the globe. The respective choices are done automatically by the Internet system (depending on the traffic load on the routes) and cannot be foreseen or influenced.^[131]^\nFurthermore, according to Article 3(a) HC V and Article 5 HC XIII, a Party to an armed conflict or war is only forbidden to “[e]rect on the territory [including territorial waters] of a neutral Power a wireless telegraphy station or other apparatus for the purpose of communicating with belligerent forces on land or sea”, and pursuant to Article 3(b) HC V to “[u]se any installation of this kind established by them [i.e. belligerents] before the war on the territory of a neutral Power for purely military purposes, and which has not been opened for the service of public messages”. This means that belligerents are allowed to use all non-purely military means of communication erected or established on the territory of a neutral State – by whomever – before the armed conflict or war. This would apply to all technical installations on the territory of\n^[130]^ Jensen, *supra* note 105, pp. 238 et seq.\n^[131]^ Walker, *supra* note 127, pp. 1079 et seq.\n\nthe neutral State being part of the worldwide, already existing computer network Internet, as it is – also historically – a communication means used by civilians also. It is asserted within academic writings that the establishment of a connection to the Internet as such should be deemed as similar to the forbidden “erecting” of a “communication apparatus”. However, it is more convincing to compare the establishment of a connection to the Internet to connecting to the worldwide telephone system by dialling a phone number – which would surely not be considered as forbidden “erecting” a “communication apparatus” by a belligerent.\nFinally, it must be endorsed that, because the law of neutrality does provide special provisions referring to communication systems on land or in territorial waters (Art. 3 HC V and Art. 5 HC XIII), there is no need or space for an (analogous) application of rules relating to the innocent passage through territorial waters, as asserted in some scholar writings.\n## IV. Concluding Remarks\nGiven the developments in technology and reliance on computer systems, in the future, CNO are likely to be of considerable significance for the planning and conduct of military operations. One of the reasons is that both the equipment and the conduct of CNO are extremely inexpensive when compared to conventional military operations. In addition, CNO can be conducted by only a few experts and from any location distant from the (traditional) area of combat, which safeguards the physical protection of the members of armed forces involved. Furthermore, as mentioned above, within the context of so-called asymmetric warfare, CNO can be a powerful weapon in the hands of non-state actors against the technologically highly developed armed forces of post-industrial States sensitive to malfunctions of their computer networks.\nOwing to the potential physical effects of CNO, the Parties to any future armed conflict in which CNO will be carried out, either in support of conventional military abilities or as the only method of war fighting conducted, will have to observe relevant LOAC provisions. The spirit and purpose of these protection granting rules, as well as the values they reflect, are timeless. They offer a level of humanitarian protection comparable to that applicable to the use of conventional weapons.\n *Id.*\n Such an assertion is made by Walker, *supra* note 127.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nNeither a lack of regulation nor a need for amendment of “aged” norms can be identified, when a teleological interpretation of the provisions is applied.\nThe future practice of the armed forces will show whether adjustments in the interpretation of relevant LOAC provisions will have to be made. The practice of the international community will decide, whether in the future it will be considered necessary to increase the level of the humanitarian protection during armed conflicts, and thus to include protection e.g. of data contained in computers or computer networks of non-combatants. Unquestionably, lawyers advising armed forces will have ever more to deal with corresponding questions of law and to understand the technical details of CNO as an emerging weapon, means or method of war.\n\n## Summary – Résumé – Samenvatting – Zusammenfassung – Riassunto – Resumen\n## Summary – Computer Network Operations and the Law of Armed Conflict\nThe Internet has become the most essential means of communication and information. This results in a high dependency upon reliable operations of Internet based communication systems, especially those supporting critical infrastructure systems. Given the shortcomings of the Internet with regard to security, the vulnerability of computer systems has become a significant matter of (national or collective) security to many States as well as to NATO. The potential conduct of “Computer Network Operations” (CNO), i.e. military defensive or offensive actions taken by the means of the Internet or other computer networks, presents some legal challenges. This survey first examines the nature of CNO and discusses the difficulties of identification of the origin and of attribution of a malicious action carried out via or in the cyberspace to a certain actor. After the presentation of some criteria for the qualification of CNO as “use of armed force” (in the *ius in bello* meaning), the survey argues that the Laws of Armed Conflict, including the over hundred years old principles and provisions of neutrality, do apply to CNO. At the same time, it demonstrates that the provisions offer a level of humanitarian protection comparable to that applicable to the use of conventional weapons.\n## Résumé – Les Opérations contre les Réseaux Informatiques et le Droit des Confits Armés\nL’internet est devenu un moyen de communication et d’information indispensable. Il en résulte une grande dépendance envers la fiabilité du fonctionnement des systèmes de communication basé sur l’internet, particulièrement ceux au soutien d’infrastructures critiques. Étant donné les insuffisances de l’internet en matière de sécurité, la vulnérabilité des systèmes d’ordinateurs est devenue un sujet important pour la sécurité (nationale et collective) de plusieurs États ainsi que pour l’OTAN. La conduite éventuelle d’Opérations contre les Réseaux Informatiques (OCRI), à savoir des actions militaires offensives ou défensives prises grâce aux moyens mêmes de l’internet ou de réseaux d’ordinateurs, présente quelques défis juridiques. Cet article examine d’abord la nature des OCRI et discute des difficultés associées à l’identification de l’origine et de l’attribution à un acteur précis d’une action malicieuse\n\nexécutée à travers ou au sein du cyber espace. Après avoir présenté quelques critères pour qualifier les OCRI comme étant une utilisation de la force armée (au sens *ius in bello*) l'auteur soutient ensuite que le droit des conflits armés ainsi que les principes et dispositions plus que centenaire en matière de neutralité s'appliquent aux OCRI. Par la même occasion, l'article démontre que ces dispositions offrent un niveau de protection humanitaire qui est comparable à celui en vigueur pour l'utilisation des armes classiques.\n## Samenvatting – Computer netwerk operaties en het humanitair oorlogsrecht\nHet Internet is uitgegroeid tot het belangrijkste communicatie- en informatiemiddel. Dit heeft geleid tot een grote afhankelijkheid van op Internet gebaseerde communicatiesystemen, vooral van die systemen die kritische infrastructuur ondersteunen. Door de beperkingen van het Internet op het gebied van beveiliging, is de kwetsbaarheid van computersystemen een zaak van (nationale of collectieve) veiligheid geworden voor veel staten en voor de NAVO. Computer netwerk operaties (CNO), dat wil zeggen defensieve of offensieve militaire handelingen door middel van Internet of andere computernetwerken, roept juridische vragen op. Dit artikel onderzoekt eerst wat CNO is en bespreekt de moeilijkheden rond het identificeren van de bron van en toerekening aan een bepaalde actor van een vijandige handeling die in of via cyberspace wordt uitgevoerd. Nadat een aantal criteria voor de kwalificatie van CNO als geweldgebruik (in de zin van het *ius in bello*) zijn geponeerd, beargumenteert het artikel dat het humanitair oorlogsrecht, waaronder de principes en regels betreffende neutraliteit die meer dan honderd jaar oud zijn, zich lenen voor toepassing op CNO. Aangetoond wordt dat de bepalingen van het humanitair oorlogsrecht binnen dit domein een niveau van bescherming bieden dat vergelijkbaar is met het niveau dat van toepassing is op het gebruik van conventionele wapens.\n## Zusammenfassung – Computernetwerkoperationen und das humanitäre Völkerrecht\nDas Internet wurde zu einem essentiellen Kommunikations- und Informationsmittel unserer Zeit. Dies führte zu einer hochgradigen Abhängigkeit von der Funktionsfähigkeit der auf dem Internet basierenden Kommunikationssysteme. Dies gilt insbesondere für diejenigen Systeme, die kritische Infrastruktursysteme eines Staates\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010)\nunterstützen. Da das Internet in Bezug auf die Sicherheit Mängel aufweist, wurde die Integrität von Computersystemen für manche Staaten so wie auch für die NATO zu einer Frage der (nationalen bzw. kollektiven) Sicherheit. Das potenzielle Durchführen von Computernetzwerkoperationen (CNO), d.h. defensiven oder offensiven Handlungen der Streitkräfte unter Inanspruchnahme des Internet oder anderer Computernetzwerke, bietet einige Herausforderungen rechtlicher Art. In dem vorliegenden Artikel wird zunächst die Natur von CNO dargelegt. Ferner werden die Schwierigkeiten in Bezug auf die Identifizierung des Ursprungs und die Zurechnung einer im virtuellen Raum vorgenommenen schädigenden Handlung zu einem bestimmten Akteur erörtert. Nachdem einige Kriterien für die Einordnung von CNO als „Anwendung bewaffneter Gewalt“ (im Sinne des *ius in bello*) vorgestellt werden, wird dargelegt, dass das humanitäre Völkerrecht, einschließlich der über hundert Jahre alten Prinzipien und Regelungen des Neutralitätsrechts, auf CNO anwendbar ist. Zugleich wird dargelegt, dass das humanitäre Völkerrecht hierbei einen humanitären Schutzstandard bietet, der demjenigen gleicht, der bei der Anwendung konventioneller Waffen gilt.\n## Riassunto – Computer Network Operations e il diritto dei conflitti armati\nLa rete internet è divenuta il più importante mezzo di comunicazione ed informazione dell’era contemporanea. Ciò determina una sostanziale dipendenza dal corretto funzionamento dei sistemi di comunicazione basati su tale rete, specialmente per ciò che concerne quelli di sostegno ad infrastrutture critiche. Vista la scarsa sicurezza della comunicazione via internet, la vulnerabilità dei sistemi informatici è diventata una questione di rilievo per la sicurezza (nazionale o collettiva) di molti stati e per la NATO. La potenziale condotta di ‘Operazioni militari su reti informatiche’ (*Computer Network Operations – CNO*), ovvero operazioni militari difensive o offensive scatenate tramite internet o per altra via informatica, presenta tuttavia talune incertezze dal punto di vista giuridico. Dapprima questo articolo esamina la vera natura delle CNO, mettendo in luce le difficoltà di identificazione e attribuzione di un’azione delittuosa portata avanti nello spazio cibernetico (o mediante quest’ultimo), a danno di un determinato soggetto. Successivamente, dopo aver presentato alcuni criteri guida per una corretta qualificazione delle CNO come un vero e proprio “uso della forza armata” (secondo lo *ius in bello*), l’articolo dimostra che il diritto dei conflitti armati, assieme agli ultra-centenari principi e norme sulla neutralità, trova applicazione\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010)\nin caso di CNO. Allo stesso modo, lo scritto evidenzia come tali norme offrano un livello di protezione umanitaria comparabile con quello applicabile nel caso di uso di armi convenzionali.\n## Resumen – Operaciones a través de la red informática y Derecho de los Conflictos Armados.\nInternet ha acabado por convertirse en un importante medio de comunicación e información de la era contemporánea. Esto lleva consigo un alto grado de dependencia con respecto a los sistemas de comunicación centrados en la red, especialmente por lo que se refiere a los sistemas que sirven de apoyo a infraestructuras vitales. Vista la escasa seguridad de las comunicaciones a través de internet, la vulnerabilidad de los sistemas de información se ha convertido en una cuestión prioritaria para la seguridad (nacional y colectiva) de muchos Estados así como para la OTAN. Las conductas potenciales que pueden ser objeto de las operaciones a través de la red informática (Computer Network Operations – CNO), como por ejemplo acciones militares tanto ofensivas como defensivas llevadas a cabo a través de internet o de otras redes de información, presentan aspectos interesantes desde el punto de vista jurídico. El presente artículo examina en primer lugar la naturaleza de las CNO y analiza las dificultades que existen para identificar el sistema en el que tiene su origen un ataque y la posterior atribución de una conducta delictiva llevada a cabo en el espacio cibernético (o a través de este último) a un sujeto determinado. Tras la exposición de algunos criterios que permiten calificar las CNO como “uso de fuerza armada” (en el sentido del *ius in bello*), el artículo demuestra que el Derecho de los Conflictos Armados resulta de aplicación a las CNO, incluidos los principios y preceptos ultra-centenarios relativos a la neutralidad. Al mismo tiempo, pone de manifiesto cómo ese Derecho ofrece un nivel de protección humanitaria comparable con el que es de aplicación en el campo del uso de armas convencionales.",

      "## 1. Forms and Effects of CNO The concept of CNO covers the following activities: defence against a cyber attack launched against one’s own computer networks (Computer Network Defence – CND), information and intelligence gathering from adversary computer networks (Computer Network Exploitation – CNE) and the conduct of a cyber attack against adversary’s computer networks (Computer Network Attack – CNA)."
    ],

      1,
      "## A. CND CND is the protection of one’s own computer systems against cyber attacks or illegal access. It includes protection of access to the networks, e.g. by passwords, the constant analysis of all hacking efforts and the continuous improvement of security standards. These improvements can comprise particular security settings in one’s own operating systems (e.g. closing of identified security gaps), establishment of respective network protection structures (e.g. individual assignment of so-called ports, i.e. “entrance/exit doors” for data streams) and firewalls, the installation of special software detecting intrusions and, if available, a honey net (i.e. a computer network established outside and around REVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010) one’s own network serving as a *quasi* buffer zone).¹⁶ The terms “active defence in cyberspace” or “active CND”, every now and then used in media reports or even military policies,¹⁷ merely refers to launching a cyber counter-attack against the cyber attacker’s computer networks, thus using means of CNA."
    ],

      1,
      "## B. CNE According to NATO’s Glossary of Terms and Definitions, CNE is an “action taken to make use of a computer or computer network, as well as the information hosted therein, in order to gain advantage”.¹⁸ This kind of “electronic intelligence gathering” aims at information about the architecture of the targeted network (*network-mapping*), the operating system data (*footprinting*) and, finally, all data saved in adversary systems, which contain information in the common sense. Consequently, CNE should be considered as a form of modern electronic espionage."
    ],

NATO’s Glossary of Terms and Definitions defines CNA as an “action taken to disrupt, deny, degrade or destroy information resident in a computer and/or computer network, or the computer and/or computer network itself”.²⁴ These are all forms of manipulation, suppression or deletion of data in adversary networks, or the delay, suppression or interruption of data transfer processes. The methods, means and techniques of CNA are manifold (e.g. breaking of passwords, injecting malware²⁵). The effects can involve either the system or the user level (e.g. delay or interruption of data transfer) and can indirectly cause physical damage outside the targeted computer networks."

The Applicability of the Laws of Armed Conflict According to common Article 2 of the GCs, LOAC applies to all cases of declared war or of any other armed conflict which may arise between two or more of the High Contracting Parties, even if the state of war is not recognized by one of them. The Convention shall also apply to all cases of partial or total occupation of the territory of a High Contracting Party, even if the said occupation meets with no armed resistance."
    ],

The Use of Telecommunication Means Belonging to a Neutral State 87 D. Data Streams Passing the Territory of a Neutral State 88 IV. Concluding Remarks 89 Summary - Résumé - Samenvatting - Zuzammenfassung - Riassunto - Resumen 91 MILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010) # I. Introduction In this day and age, the Internet¹ is one of the most important means of communication and information. During the last 30 years it has gradually become an essential aspect of the economy in a globalized world and plays an indispensable role in, amongst other things, the administrative and judicial systems of technologically developed countries. All in all, critical infrastructure systems in States with high levels of technology dependency are acutely reliant upon reliable and effective operations of Internet based communication systems. Thus, given the shortcomings of the Internet with regard to the security, protection and defence of the integrity of computer networks, the vulnerability of these communication systems has become a significant matter of national security to many such States. Accordingly, the current National Security Strategies of the USA², of the United Kingdom³, ¹ The Internet is globally administered by a Californian (US) non-profit, public-benefit corporation, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) which, in the framework of a Public Private Partnership, is associated with and reports to the US Department of Commerce (although, according to the information on ICANN’s website, the organisation heavily emphasises its international nature and independence). ICANN bears global responsibility for ensuring the stable and secure operation of the Internet as well as for coordinating the Internet system of unique identifiers, i.e. for the assignment of IP-address ranges (since 2005 not directly to users but to regional organisations – see infra note 58). It is further responsible for the generic codes and country codes of the Internet top level domain as well as for the management and maintenance of the (secret) Internet root server system (see infra note 122). ICANN is the successor organization of the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA), which was executing the above-mentioned tasks directly on behalf of the US Department of Commerce (information available at http://www.icann/org/en/factsheets/factsheet.html; unless indicated otherwise, all URLs cited in the present survey were last visited on 31 November 2010). Originally, it was planned to transform ICANN into an independent organization in October 2006. During the 2nd World Summit on the Information Society, organized by the UN in Tunis in November 2005, it was proposed to submit ICANN (and thus the Internet itself) to management by the UN. The USA rejected this proposal and declared its intent to keep the control over ICANN for the time being (information available at http://www.itu.int/wsis/).\n² The President of the United States of America, National Security Strategy (May 2010), p. 27 et seq., available at http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/rss_viewer/national_security_strategy.pdf.\n³ Her Majesty’s Government, A Strong Britain in an Age of Uncertainty: The National Security Strategy (October 2010), pp. 11 and 27, available at http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/documents/digitalasset/dg_191639.pdf?CID=PDF&amp;PLA=furl&amp;CRE=nationalsecuritystrategy.\nand Germany’s Federal Ministry of Defence White Paper,⁴ all seek to address the issue of cyber-attacks. According to NATO’s new Strategic Concept of 19 November 2010, cyber threats are one of the major perils for the security of the Alliance in the future decade.⁵ Similar concerns are reflected in resolutions adopted by the United Nations General Assembly over the last ten years, which regularly mention the integrity of information and communication technology in the context of international security and call for the creation of a global “culture of cyber security”.⁶ Additionally, the emerging threat of the use of ⁴ Federal Ministry of Defence, White Paper 2006 on German Security Policy and the Future of the Bundeswehr (2006), p. 17: “Germany’s political and economic structures as well as its critical infrastructure have become more vulnerable as a result, not least where criminal activities, terrorist acts, or military attacks from or on cyberspace are concerned”; available at http://www.bmvg.de/fileserving/PortalFiles/C1256EF40036B05B/W26UWAMT995INFODE/W%202006%20eng%20DS.pdf.\n⁵ NATO, Strategic Concept For the Defence and Security of The Members of the North Atlantic Treaty Adopted by Heads of State and Government in Lisbon (19 November 2010), §§ 12 and 19, available at http://www.nato.int/lisbon2010/strategic-concept-2010-eng.pdf. See also NATO, Heads of State and Government participating in the meeting of the North Atlantic Council in Lisbon, Lisbon Summit Declaration (20 November 2010), § 40: “Cyber threats are rapidly increasing and evolving in sophistication. In order to ensure NATO’s permanent and unfettered access to cyberspace and integrity of its critical systems, we will take into account the cyber dimension of modern conflicts in NATO’s doctrine and improve its capabilities to detect, assess, prevent, defend and recover in case of a cyber attack against systems of critical importance to the Alliance. We will strive in particular to accelerate NATO Computer Incident Response Capability (NCIRC) to Full Operational Capability (FOC) by 2012 and the bringing of all NATO bodies under centralized cyber protection. We will use NATO’s defence planning processes in order to promote the development of Allies’ cyber defence capabilities, to assist individual Allies upon request, and to optimize information sharing, collaboration and interoperability. To address the security risks emanating from cyberspace, we will work closely with other actors, such as the UN and the EU, as agreed. We have tasked the Council to develop, drawing notably on existing international structures and on the basis of a review of our current policy, a NATO in-depth cyber defence policy by June 2011 and to prepare an action plan for its implementation”; available at http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/official_texts_68828.htm.\n⁶ See the resolutions Developments in the field of information and telecommunications in the context of international security, UN Documents A/53/70 of 4 December 1998, A/54/49 of 1 December 1999, A/55/28 of 20 November 2000, A/56/19 of 29 November 2001, A/57/53 of 22 November 2002, A/58/32 of 8 December 2003, A/59/61 of 3 December 2004, A/60/45 of 8 December 2005, A/61/55 of 6 December 2006, and A/62/17 of 5 December 2007. With regard to the creation of a global culture of cyber security, see the resolutions Creation of a global culture of cybersecurity and the protection of critical information structures, MILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010) the Internet for terrorist purposes (cyber terrorism) is currently on the agendas of several international initiatives and programmes.7 Military forces use the Internet for communication purposes and – to a certain extent – as an inherent component of particular weapon systems. Additionally, the Internet offers the possibility for offensive and/or defensive military actions by the means of the Internet or other computer networks. The military term “Computer Network Operations” (CNO) refers, generally speaking, to computer hacking and back-hacking in the context of a military operation.\nWorldwide, military forces are preparing for the fight in cyberspace. It has been alleged that Israeli armed forces have engaged in CNO activities since the early 1990s.8 The USA established a US Cyber Command (USCYBERCOM) in Fort Meade, Maryland on 23 June 2009 (operational as of October 2010) which unified the already existing cyber capabilities of the US National Security Agency and several US military services (Army Forces Cyber Command, 24th US Air Force, Fleet Cyber Command and Marine Forces Cyber Command).9 According to media reports, Belgium10, Germany11, South Korea12 (allegedly in reaction to respective North Korean endeavours), and the UN Documents A/55/63 of 4 December 2000, A/56/121 of 19 December 2001, A/57/239 of 20 December 2002, and A/58/199 of 23 December 2003.\nUnited Kingdom (Government Communications Headquarters)¹³ have established similar commands in 2009, while China¹⁴ did so in 2010.¹⁵ Undeniably, CNO have become an important weapon, means or method of warfare extending the – traditionally clearly defined – battlefield to the global cyberspace. Especially because cyberspace seems to be “boundless”, many scholars claim that the existing rules of public international law, traditionally based on the notion of State sovereignty and thus State borders, do not meet the legal challenges which CNO present.\nThe purpose of this paper is to argue that the Laws of Armed Conflict (LOAC) apply to military defensive or offensive actions taken by the means of the Internet or other computer networks. At the same time, it will demonstrate that the provisions of LOAC offer a level of humanitarian protection comparable to that applicable to the use of conventional weapons. Due to the focus of this paper, the question whether and under which circumstances CNO can be considered as an armed attack pursuant to Article 51 of the United Nations Charter (UN Charter) or Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty will be not examined. Therefore, whenever the term “cyber attack” is used, it does not aim to indicate that an “armed attack” in the legal sense has necessarily occurred.\nIn the following, the nature and the significance of CNO will be described (II). Thereafter, the legal analysis of CNO as pertaining to LOAC will be examined (III). These sections will be followed by some concluding remarks (IV).\n¹³ See C. Clark, ‘StratCom Plows Ahead on Cyber’, Online Defense and Acquisition Journal of 29 June 2009, available at http://www.dodbuzz.com/2009/06/29/stratcom-plows-ahead-on-cyber/.\n¹⁴ T. Branigen, ‘Chinese Army to Target Cyber War Threat’, Guardian online of 22 July 2010, available at http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/jul/22/chinese-army-cyber-war-department.\n¹⁵ According to some reports, Chinese armed forces built up CNO capabilities already some years ago, see e.g. Northrop Grumman Corporation - Information Systems Sector, Capability of the People’s Republic of China to Conduct Cyber Warfare and Computer Network Exploitation (Report of 9 October 2009 Prepared for The U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission), available at http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2009/NorthropGrumman_PRC_Cyber_Paper_FINAL_Approved%20Report_16Oct2009.pdf.\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010) ## II. The Nature and Significance of CNO In the following paragraphs, the various forms and effects of CNO will be examined (1). Next, the challenge of the attribution of a cyber attack will be discussed (2). Finally, the significance of CNO for the conduct of military operations in the context of contemporary armed conflicts will be addressed (3).",
    "## 1. Forms and Effects of CNO The concept of CNO covers the following activities: defence against a cyber attack launched against one’s own computer networks (Computer Network Defence – CND), information and intelligence gathering from adversary computer networks (Computer Network Exploitation – CNE) and the conduct of a cyber attack against adversary’s computer networks (Computer Network Attack – CNA).": "The above-mentioned components of CNO are strongly interrelated. An adversary’s CNA can help one’s own CND when analysed appropriately. A CNE cannot be conducted without CNA, as the information to be gathered by CNE will mostly be protected by firewalls, passwords and other barriers that are erected to prevent an adversarial CNA. Finally, CNA cannot be conducted without CNE, as without information gathering on the targeted network’s architecture and systems the CNA would effectively be conducted blindly.\nWhile the practical value of the taxonomy of CND/CNE/CNA therefore is questionable, it will be presented in more detail below as most academic writings and media reports refer to this classification.",
    "## A. CND CND is the protection of one’s own computer systems against cyber attacks or illegal access. It includes protection of access to the networks, e.g. by passwords, the constant analysis of all hacking efforts and the continuous improvement of security standards. These improvements can comprise particular security settings in one’s own operating systems (e.g. closing of identified security gaps), establishment of respective network protection structures (e.g. individual assignment of so-called ports, i.e. “entrance/exit doors” for data streams) and firewalls, the installation of special software detecting intrusions and, if available, a honey net (i.e. a computer network established outside and around REVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010) one’s own network serving as a *quasi* buffer zone).¹⁶ The terms “active defence in cyberspace” or “active CND”, every now and then used in media reports or even military policies,¹⁷ merely refers to launching a cyber counter-attack against the cyber attacker’s computer networks, thus using means of CNA.": "",
    "## B. CNE According to NATO’s Glossary of Terms and Definitions, CNE is an “action taken to make use of a computer or computer network, as well as the information hosted therein, in order to gain advantage”.¹⁸ This kind of “electronic intelligence gathering” aims at information about the architecture of the targeted network (*network-mapping*), the operating system data (*footprinting*) and, finally, all data saved in adversary systems, which contain information in the common sense. Consequently, CNE should be considered as a form of modern electronic espionage.": "According to open source reports, the vast majority of CNO activities conducted during peacetime consist of CNE. For example, already in 2007, the British intelligence service MI5 warned all financial service providers and companies in Great Britain against concerted cyber espionage endeavours by the Chinese People’s Liberation Army.¹⁹ In summer 2007, the computer systems of Germany’s Federal Chancellery as well as those of some federal ministries were infected with spyware (i.e. espionage software) reported to have originated from China.²⁰ According to the Annual Report 2009 of the German Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, computer systems of Germany’s federal and state governments and of private businesses were targeted by hundreds of (successful and/or unsuccessful) CNE. Foreign intelligence MILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010) services were likely to be the organizers of, or are involved in, most of these.²¹ In the USA, over 100 foreign intelligence services currently endeavour to intrude computer systems located in the country, as the US Deputy Secretary of Defence stated in September 2010.²² NATO’s computer networks are also subject to constant – and partly successful – CNE.²³ There is no open source information as to the employment of CNE during an armed conflict. However, it can be assumed that CNE is very likely to be used in support of military intelligence, reconnaissance and surveillance.",
    "## C. CNA CNA can cause multiple effects. NATO’s Glossary of Terms and Definitions defines CNA as an “action taken to disrupt, deny, degrade or destroy information resident in a computer and/or computer network, or the computer and/or computer network itself”.²⁴ These are all forms of manipulation, suppression or deletion of data in adversary networks, or the delay, suppression or interruption of data transfer processes. The methods, means and techniques of CNA are manifold (e.g. breaking of passwords, injecting malware²⁵). The effects can involve either the system or the user level (e.g. delay or interruption of data transfer) and can indirectly cause physical damage outside the targeted computer networks.": "Relatively harmless, data modification in the course of a CNA can modify and deface a website (defacement). This is often conducted by hackers who wish to express their political view (hacktivism). Another widely spread form of CNA is the Distributed-Denial-of-Service attack REVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010) (DDoS-attack),²⁶ which can cause delays in the data transfer process, the denial of access to computer systems or servers (e.g. the targeted websites or a email service) or result in the (only temporary) disabling of the targeted systems. The particular DDoS-techniques are as diverse as the – partly very effective – countermeasures²⁷ developed since 2000.\nHowever, the deletion or modification of data in a successfully intruded computer network can be more hazardous. Hackers can generate wrong information, for instance in the military environment the content of electronically transmitted orders, plans and maps or the localization data of military targets contained in a targeting-database.\nMoreover, it is possible that a CNA could – indirectly – cause death, physical injury or physical destruction of property. As far as chemical plants, nuclear power stations, oil refinery installations, gas store installations or electrical power distribution installations have or rely on computer-based control systems, these systems could be penetrated and manipulated. Thus, a CNA could cause the explosion of a nuclear power plant if the cooling systems were disabled via remote control. The same applies to computer-based control systems of transportation systems. By manipulation of the rail points, train derailments or collisions could be caused; penetration and minimal amendments to the programming of an air traffic control system could result in aircraft incidents. Therefore, the classification of CNO as a non-lethal weapon, as asserted by some scholars,²⁸ has to be challenged in this regard. Also, the general assertion made that CNO, in its current form would generally not violate LOAC, is questionable.²⁹ Above all, CNA can affect the functioning of a State, when manipulating or deleting data in computer systems of critical infrastructure systems. The list of critical infrastructure systems will slightly differ from State to State. By way of example, the following areas identified by the German Federal Office of Security of Information Technology (Bundesamt für Sicherheit in der Informationstechnik) can be considered as critical infrastructure systems:³⁰ transportation and traffic (postal services, local traffic, roads, rail system, aviation, sea and inland navigation); energy (nuclear plants, distribution and transfer systems of electricity, oil, gas); hazardous substances (chemical and biological agents, nuclear reactors); information and telecommunication technology; finance, currency and insurance (banks, insurance companies, financial service providers, stock markets); public utilities (health, emergency and rescue sector, disaster control, food and water supply, waste management); government, administration, justice, police, customs and armed forces.\nMany of these critical infrastructure systems are based on computer-based control systems, such as the generation and distribution of electricity or telecommunications. Some function entirely on the basis of an Internet connection, including the banking and stock exchange systems. Other areas are increasingly reliant on the Internet, for example the so-called e-justice and e-government. In any technologically highly developed, post-industrial State most of the critical infrastructure systems can be deemed to depend on the operability and efficiency of electronic data transfer. The devastating effects and the subsequent disruption of the ordre public caused by a CNA are limited only by the imagination of the reader. Therefore, cyber security plays a paramount role for the national security of many States and was noted as one of the major perils for the Alliance's security in NATO's Strategic Concept of 2010 (see supra I).\nThere is open source information available in the media on CNA being conducted during peacetime.\nThe only publicly known case, in which the attribution of a CNA to a particular State can be asserted, was the penetration and temporary disabling of Syrian air defence networks, especially the radar systems, by Israel on 6 September 2007, immediately followed by an airstrike by Israel's Air Force destroying Syria's Al Kibar nuclear reactor in Deir-Az-Zur.³¹ ³⁰ See the list of critical infrastructure systems, available at https://www.bsi.bund.de/cln_183/ContentBSI/Publikationen/Faltblaetter/F17KritischeInfrastruktur.html.\n³¹ Ben-David, supra note 8.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010) A more prominent case of a successful CNA against a State are the DDoS-attacks launched against several critical infrastructure systems in Estonia during the 27 April – 18 May 2007 timeframe. The “attacks”³² targeted websites and communication channels of the government and commercial services.³³ For example, the web-services of the major banks Hansapank and SEB Eesti Ühispank were (at one-time) interrupted for 1,5 hours;³⁴ the website of a governing coalition party was defaced;³⁵ emergency phone numbers were disengaged for a short time;³⁶ and three major Estonian Internet Service Providers and some online news providers were disconnected (although it is unclear for how long).³⁷ The estimated physical (because of the disengagement of emergency phone numbers) and economic damage caused by the DDoS-attacks remains unclear. The attacks most probably originated from the territory of the Russian Federation. Given the relatively simple DDoS-methods and the political context of the relocation of a Soviet war memorial in Tallinn, it is asserted that the “attackers” were politically motivated private persons (hacktivism).³⁸ Another example of successful CNA during peacetime are the defacement and DDoS-attacks launched against Lithuania between 28 June and 1 July 2008. The CNA may have been connected either to the amendment of Lithuania’s laws to prohibit the display of symbols of the Soviet Union or the singing of its anthem in public³⁹ or to the unilateral veto⁴⁰ against discussions on an EU energy partnership deal with Russian Federation. Over 300 Lithuanian websites were defaced, including those of the Government.⁴¹ Given the pro-Russian contents of the defacement, as well as the subject of the (unsolicited) spam emails “Hackers United against external threats to Russia”, the CNA is assumed to have originated with nationalistic, private hacker groups (hacktivism).42 On the contrary, the “Conficker” worm, reported to have been created by Russian criminals, was not aimed at State structures, as it spread worldwide, affecting both private and official networks. It did gain national interest of the victim States, when it began to affect governmental and military computer systems, including those of the British Parliament,43 and the French and British air forces and navies.44 The worm “Stuxnet”, which affected over 100.000 computer systems worldwide between June and September 2010, targeted industrial control systems of gas pipelines and power plants based on Siemens software, aiming to establish remote control of the systems and to hide any changes in the computer systems from the operators of the equipment.45 As the vast majority of the infections affected Iran’s critical infrastructure systems, in particular of the nuclear power plant near Bushehr, and the worm’s reach and complexity obviously required enormous personnel and budgetary investments as well as a considerable amount of time to write the code (in secrecy), the involvement of a foreign organization or State is suspected.46 Although there is no respective open source information, it must be assumed that, in the past, CNA were also successfully launched against NATO’s computer systems. The *Analysis and Recommendations of the Group of Experts on a New Strategic Concept for NATO* presented on 17 May 2010 noted: “Already, cyber attacks against NATO systems occur frequently, but most often below the threshold of political concern”.⁴⁷ Furthermore, CNA were conducted during times of armed conflict, as for example during *Operation Allied Force*⁴⁸ (24 March – 10 June 1999) launched by 10 NATO Member States⁴⁹ against Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. At the beginning of the operation, websites and the mailing system of NATO were blocked and infected by a virus (Melissa), apparently originating in Serbia.⁵⁰ Furthermore, some defacement attacks were launched by politically motivated individuals (hacktivism) from Serbia and Russia (*Black Hand, From Russia with Love, Russian Hacker Union*, etc.) against websites of NATO and NATO Member States.⁵¹ Equally, some hackers groups (politically) supporting the NATO operation (e.g. *Dutchthreat* or *Kosovo Hackers Group*) tried to infiltrate the governmental websites of Yugoslavia.⁵² Moreover, it is suspected that the President of the USA, *Bill Clinton*, did authorize the *Central Intelligence Agency* (CIA) to penetrate the computer systems of banks in Greece, Lebanon, Russia and Cyprus in order to clear the banking accounts of the President of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia *Slobodan Milošević*.⁵³ As the respective plans are said to have been ‘Foreign-made’ ‘Stuxnet’ Computer Virus’, *The Washington Post* online of 27 September 2010, available at http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/27/AR2010092706229.html.\n⁴⁷ NATO, *NATO 2020: Assured Security, Dynamic Engagement. Analysis and Recommendations of the Group of Experts on a New Strategic Concept for NATO* (17 May 2010), p. 45, available at http://www.nato.int/strategic-concept/expertsreport.pdf.\n⁴⁸ For details of the operation, see http://www.nato.int/kosovo/all-frce.htm; for information on the role of NATO in Kosovo, see http://www.nato.int/kosovo/history.htm.\n⁴⁹ The following NATO Member States took active part in the “Operation Allied Force: Canada, Belgium, Denmark, Germany, Great Britain, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, Turkey and USA.\n⁵⁰ See ‘Access to NATO’s Web Site Disrupted’, *CNN News* online of 31 March 1999, available at http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9903/31/nato.hack/; see also NATO, ‘Defending against cyber-attacks’, available at http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/topics_49193.htm.\n⁵¹ R. Bendrath, ‘Der Kosovo-Krieg im Cyberspace’, *heise online* of 19 July 1999, available at http://www.heise.de/tp/r4/artikel/6/6449/1.html.\n⁵² *Id.* ⁵³ See ‘Serbs Flee Yugoslavia’, *BBC News* online of 25 May 1999, available at http:// MILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010) objected within the US-Congress due to possible diplomatic friction and potential loss of trust in regard to the international banking system, it remains unclear whether the CNO was conducted.⁵⁴ Also, in the weeks before and during the course of the five-day hostilities between the Russian Federation and Georgia (South Ossetia) which started on 8 August 2008, significant CNO were launched against Georgia.⁵⁵ Those were DDoS-attacks and defacements mainly directed against Georgian government websites but also the web portals of Georgia’s National Bank and news agencies, partly resulting in shutting down the website servers for hours or days.⁵⁶ Although suspicions of the – officially disclaimed – involvement of the Russian Federation in the cyber incidents remain, these incidences were allegedly attributed to the criminal organization “Russian Business Network” (hosting and renting illegal web services).⁵⁷ In regard to the aforementioned armed conflicts, it can be inferred that the conduct of CNO did partly influence the perception of the conflict in the public, but not its overall outcome. It can be assumed that also in the near future CNO are very likely to be used merely in support of a conventional military operation, mainly military intelligence, reconnaissance and surveillance, or in order to influence the perception of a particular political conflict in the online media.",
    "## 2. Identification of the Origin and Attribution of Malicious CNO It will always be difficult to unequivocally identify the computer systems that malicious CNO originated from and to attribute the attack to a certain entity, group or a State.": "A cyber attack is distinguished by its rapidness. As soon as the attack is completed, the tracing of the data stream (so-called back-tracing) and news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/352059.stm; ‘CIA Ordered to Topple Milosevic’, BBC News online of 6 July 1999, available at http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/387463. stm; and F. Rötzer, ‘CIA im Crackerkrieg gegen Milosevich?’, heise online of 24 May 1999, available at http://www.heise.de/tp/r4/artikel/2/2874/1.html.\n⁵⁴ Id.\n⁵⁵ See Independent International Fact-Finding Mission on the Conflict in Georgia, Report (September 2009), Vol. II., pp. 217 et seq., available at http://www.ceig.ch/pdf/IIFFMCG_Volume_II.pdf; and J. Markoff, ‘Before the Gunfire, Cyberattacks’, The New York Times online of 13 August 2008, available at http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/13/technology/13cyber.html?_r=2&amp;em.\n⁵⁶ For more details, see id.\n⁵⁷ Id.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010) thus the identification of the originating computer system are highly improbable. It is highly unlikely that hackers will leave any tangible evidence, for example in the protocols of the intrusion detection systems of the attacked network, as such evidence in these protocols is easy to delete once the network is penetrated.\nMoreover, and further aggravating the issue, a cyber-attack can be conducted “anonymously”, for example by using one of the (often) free of charge anonymisation services offered on the Internet which would hide the unique characteristics of the hackers’ computer system. These unique characteristics are the so-called IP address⁵⁸ as well as other technical data⁵⁹ a computer sends while connected to the Internet.\n⁵⁸ An IP address (Internet Protocol number) is a twelve digit number, which identifies a computer or another network device during an Internet session. An IP data package is the basic element of data transmission via the Internet. It comprises: a header (containing information on the source, destination, status and fragmentation of the transmitted data) and a payload (containing the transmitted data). At the very beginning of the Internet, the IANA (see supra note 1) assigned static IP addresses, i.e. IP addresses permanently assigned to a particular user, to companies, organizations, universities and also to individuals. The assignment of IP addresses to individual users or of IP address ranges to Internet Access Providers is now regulated by ICANN (see supra note 1). Since February 2005, ICANN delegates this task to five Regional Internet Registries (RIR), i.e. regional organisations assigning IP addresses. These are AfriNIC (Africa), APNIC (Asia and Pacific), ARIN (North America), LACNIC (Latin America and Caribbean Region) and RIPE NCC (Europe, Near East and Central Asia). The regional organisations assign the IP addresses to local organisations, mainly to Internet Service Providers (e.g. yahoo, gmail etc). Usually, an Internet user receives from the pool of IP addresses at the disposal of an Access Provider a specific (dynamic) IP address for the particular Internet session only. After the particular Internet session the dynamic IP address is assigned to another user and client of the respective Access Provider. At present, the so-called static IP-addresses are only being used for leased Internet-lines of major corporations and other entities.\n⁵⁹ These include: Media Access Control address (MAC address) or – for the operating system Apple – the Airport ID of a computer (order of numbers, which clearly identifies a computer hardware); Address Resolution Protocol (ARP, details on the assignment of a MAC address or Airport ID to an IP address); Service Set Identity (SSID, details on the network name); Wired Equivalent Privacy Protocol (WEP, coded details about the network); as well as details on the operating system and its adjustments. These details are – if not blocked – automatically transferred during the Internet session to any computer requesting this information by a so-called PING (Packet InterNet Grouper). A PING is computer software sending an ICMP-Echo-Request data package to the destination address of the host which is to be scanned, i.e. to the IP address, to the Domain Name System name (DNS name) or to the Network Basic Input Output System name (NetBIOS name) of the targeted host. The targeted system automatically responds by an ICMP-Echo-Reply, if – according to the usual adjustments of the system – the system supports the ICMP package.\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010) Furthermore, the Internet offers possibilities for deception in regard to the identity of the hackers' computer systems. It is perfectly possible to feign someone else's IP address and other technical data (so-called malicious misrepresentation or spoofing) and thus to operate in the Internet under someone else's\"cyber-identity\". The connection to the Internet can also be established via a mobile phone or other device with a feigned identity number. Additionally, the data stream can be conducted through the whole globe via a chain of computers of numerous unsuspecting individuals, if so-called zombie software (partly offered free of charge on the Internet) has been secretly installed on the respective computers by using Trojans. One of these computers could subsequently be misused as the sender of the data stream (so-called remote control). Thus, in the case of a cyber attack, even after a back tracing of the malicious data stream, the victim can seldom be sure as of the identification and geographical location of the computer system the attack originated from.\nAbove all, even if a malicious data stream of a cyber attack would indeed be successfully back-traced to the hackers' computer systems, it will – highly probable – remain unproven which individuals of which citizenship and on who's orders were operating the systems identified. Therefore, the attribution of a cyber attack to a certain individual, group, entity or State will most probably be based on unproven suspicions or indications only.\nConsequently, it will be very unlikely to recognize at first sight – and probably even after detailed technical analysis – whether the attack was conducted by a mischievous teenager, by a criminal (including a terrorist), by a group with extremist or terrorist background or by the adversary Party in an armed conflict.\nThese uncertainties will surely add to the complexity of both the legal analysis of a cyber attack and the victim's decision on choosing a subsequent course of action. Considering the difficulty in identifying and locating the hackers' computer systems and – most importantly – attributing the attack, in most cases it will remain in doubt whether national police forces and public prosecutors or, in the framework of international judicial cooperation, the police forces and public prosecutors of a foreign State, or the armed forces (in the case the attack occurs during an already existing armed conflict and is believed to have originated with a party to the armed conflict, or in the case the effects of the cyber-attack are comparable to a conventional armed attack and trigger the right to self-defence) retain main responsibility to deal with the case.",
    "## 3. CNO in Modern Warfare The significance of CNO for the conduct of military operations is manifold.": "Whilst most armed conflicts in this day and age are occurring in regions that are technologically less sophisticated (e.g. Afghanistan, Sudan or Chad), this does not result in the irrelevance of the Internet and of CNO. It must be taken into consideration that, in regard to communication abilities and collection of open source information, the parties to armed conflicts in less well developed regions are also essentially dependent on – aside from radio traffic – wireless Internet connectivity, as other communication and information systems (e.g. telecommunication media, print media, telephone lines) are often non-existent.\nIt is especially evident in the context of so-called asymmetric warfare and in the hands of non-state actors, for instance terrorists, that CNO can be a powerful weapon, primarily against post-industrial States and their potent armed forces. More than ever, post-industrial States have technologically highly developed armed forces at their disposal, which correspondingly react most sensitively to technical disorder. It is the dependence on the technology which makes them extremely vulnerable to a cyber attack.\nAs CNO can be conducted from any place in the world by as little as a few experts and, in addition, are extraordinarily inexpensive when compared with conventional military operations, they offer a particularly practical and extremely powerful\"weapon\". Therefore, all aspects of CNO (see supra II.1) show an increasing significance in the context of national as well as of international security.\nAs the Head of the NATO Computer Incident Response Capability Co-ordination Centre stated already in 2008:\"Cyber war can become a very effective global problem because it is low-risk, low-cost, highly effective and easily globally deployable. It is almost an ideal weapon that nobody can ignore\".60 MILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010) ## III. Legal Analysis of CNO Although some scholars plead for a general prohibition of CNO, currently such a ban does not exist.⁶¹ However, many international and domestic legal restrictions do apply to CNO – a fact which makes a legal analysis a complex undertaking.\nApart from the fundamental principle of public international law, namely the prohibition of the threat or use of force in international relations, a number of specific areas of public international law may apply to CNO. As data packages pass through the territory of several States when sent via the Internet, the provisions of territorial sovereignty must be considered. Also, data manipulations might – under certain circumstances – be judged as intervention in domestic affairs of a State, which would be considered illegal under public international law. Further, because satellite technology is involved, space law and especially treaties relating to satellites must be considered. As CNO can interfere with telecommunication systems and always result in data amendments in the working storage of the attacked computer system, both international telecommunications law and international copyright law (in regard to software) require a thorough analysis. In case human rights treaty law is generally applicable, their respective provisions must be considered, especially in regard to secrecy of correspondence, telecommunications and data protection, as well as to the right to receive and impart information and ideas. Restraints for CNO can further result from the provisions of diplomatic and consular law, whenever diplomatic or consular computer systems are involved. Furthermore, it has been asserted that international environmental law principles of good neighbourhood and of the prevention of significant trans-boundary harm would be applicable to CNO in analogy.⁶² In addition, the provisions of ⁶¹ A. D’Amato pleads for a general prohibition of CNO, emphasizing that the stability of the international community depends on the free flow of information (p. 68) and that every nation has a vital interest in the operationability of the Internet (p. 69), see A. D’Amato, ‘International Law, Cybernetics, and Cyberspace’, in M.N. Schmitt &amp; B.T. O’Donnell (eds.), *Computer Network Attack and International Law* (Newport / Rhode Island, US Naval War College, 2002), pp. 59–71, pp. 67–69. See also: T. Morth, ‘Considering Our Position. Viewing Information Warfare as Use of Force Prohibited by Article 2(4) of the U.N. Charter’, Vol. 30 *Case Western Reserve* J.I.L. 1998, p. 600.\n⁶² Such assertion is made – emphasizing that the Internet is a global resource comparable to the natural environment – by T. Stein &amp; T. Marauhn, ‘Völkerrechtliche Aspekte von Informationsoperationen’, Vol. 60 *Zeitschrift für ausländisches öffentliches Recht und Völkerrecht* 2000, p. 21. A similar approach REVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010) respective national law systems, especially constitutional and criminal law, must always be taken into consideration.\nGiven the variety of areas of law involved and the limited scope of this survey, the following remarks will be restricted to the analysis of LOAC, focusing on the provisions of the Regulations concerning the Laws and Customs of War on Land, Annex to the Hague Convention (IV) respecting the Laws and Customs of War on Land of 18 October 1907 (HR), the four Geneva Conventions of 1949 (GC) and their Additional Protocols I (AP I) and II (AP II) (2). However, first of all, it must be examined under which conditions LOAC applies to CNO (1).",
    "## 1. The Applicability of the Laws of Armed Conflict According to common Article 2 of the GCs, LOAC applies to all cases of declared war or of any other armed conflict which may arise between two or more of the High Contracting Parties, even if the state of war is not recognized by one of them. The Convention shall also apply to all cases of partial or total occupation of the territory of a High Contracting Party, even if the said occupation meets with no armed resistance.": "In practice, armed conflicts surely can be considered as the main case of application of LOAC. Pursuant to the prevailing opinion an is taken by the (non-binding) OECD Guidelines for the Security of Information Systems of 1992, which call for cooperation of States (Principle 6) in the area of comprehensive protection of information systems (Principle 4), and which stipulate an imperative of deliberation in the use of information systems (Principle 3), see OECD Doc. OCDE/GD(92)190. However, an analogous application of international environmental law provisions is not convincing because of the lack of an “unintended omission” or of the absence of regulation. International telecommunication law, in particular the provisions of the (almost universally ratified) Constitution of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) of 22 December 1992, binds ITU Member States to far-reaching obligations in regard to the protection of communication and information systems (see in particular Articles 6, 33, 38, 45 and 47 of the ITU Constitution).\n These are: and Shipwrecked Members of Armed Forces at Sea of 12 August 1949; Convention (III) Relative to the Treatment of Prisoners of War of 12 August 1949; Convention (IV) Relative to the Protection of non-international) armed conflict and consequently the application of LOAC is given, when States or – under certain circumstances – organized armed groups use “armed force” against the other
