The Nature and Significance of CNO In the following paragraphs, the various forms and effects of CNO will be examined (1). Next, the challenge of the attribution of a cyber attack will be discussed (2). Finally, the significance of CNO for the conduct of military operations in the context of contemporary armed conflicts will be addressed (3).\n## 1. Forms and Effects of CNO The concept of CNO covers the following activities: defence against a cyber attack launched against one’s own computer networks (Computer Network Defence – CND), information and intelligence gathering from adversary computer networks (Computer Network Exploitation – CNE) and the conduct of a cyber attack against adversary’s computer networks (Computer Network Attack – CNA).\nThe above-mentioned components of CNO are strongly interrelated. An adversary’s CNA can help one’s own CND when analysed appropriately. A CNE cannot be conducted without CNA, as the information to be gathered by CNE will mostly be protected by firewalls, passwords and other barriers that are erected to prevent an adversarial CNA. Finally, CNA cannot be conducted without CNE, as without information gathering on the targeted network’s architecture and systems the CNA would effectively be conducted blindly.\nWhile the practical value of the taxonomy of CND/CNE/CNA therefore is questionable, it will be presented in more detail below as most academic writings and media reports refer to this classification.\n## A. CND CND is the protection of one’s own computer systems against cyber attacks or illegal access. It includes protection of access to the networks, e.g. by passwords, the constant analysis of all hacking efforts and the continuous improvement of security standards. These improvements can comprise particular security settings in one’s own operating systems (e.g. closing of identified security gaps), establishment of respective network protection structures (e.g. individual assignment of so-called ports, i.e. “entrance/exit doors” for data streams) and firewalls, the installation of special software detecting intrusions and, if available, a honey net (i.e. a computer network established outside and around REVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010) one’s own network serving as a *quasi* buffer zone).¹⁶ The terms “active defence in cyberspace” or “active CND”, every now and then used in media reports or even military policies,¹⁷ merely refers to launching a cyber counter-attack against the cyber attacker’s computer networks, thus using means of CNA.\n## B. CNE According to NATO’s Glossary of Terms and Definitions, CNE is an “action taken to make use of a computer or computer network, as well as the information hosted therein, in order to gain advantage”.¹⁸ This kind of “electronic intelligence gathering” aims at information about the architecture of the targeted network (*network-mapping*), the operating system data (*footprinting*) and, finally, all data saved in adversary systems, which contain information in the common sense. Consequently, CNE should be considered as a form of modern electronic espionage.\nAccording to open source reports, the vast majority of CNO activities conducted during peacetime consist of CNE. For example, already in 2007, the British intelligence service MI5 warned all financial service providers and companies in Great Britain against concerted cyber espionage endeavours by the Chinese People’s Liberation Army.¹⁹ In summer 2007, the computer systems of Germany’s Federal Chancellery as well as those of some federal ministries were infected with spyware (i.e. espionage software) reported to have originated from China.²⁰ According to the Annual Report 2009 of the German Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, computer systems of Germany’s federal and state governments and of private businesses were targeted by hundreds of (successful and/or unsuccessful) CNE. Foreign intelligence MILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010) services were likely to be the organizers of, or are involved in, most of these.²¹ In the USA, over 100 foreign intelligence services currently endeavour to intrude computer systems located in the country, as the US Deputy Secretary of Defence stated in September 2010.²² NATO’s computer networks are also subject to constant – and partly successful – CNE.²³ There is no open source information as to the employment of CNE during an armed conflict. However, it can be assumed that CNE is very likely to be used in support of military intelligence, reconnaissance and surveillance.\n## C. CNA CNA can cause multiple effects. NATO’s Glossary of Terms and Definitions defines CNA as an “action taken to disrupt, deny, degrade or destroy information resident in a computer and/or computer network, or the computer and/or computer network itself”.²⁴ These are all forms of manipulation, suppression or deletion of data in adversary networks, or the delay, suppression or interruption of data transfer processes. The methods, means and techniques of CNA are manifold (e.g. breaking of passwords, injecting malware²⁵). The effects can involve either the system or the user level (e.g. delay or interruption of data transfer) and can indirectly cause physical damage outside the targeted computer networks.\nRelatively harmless, data modification in the course of a CNA can modify and deface a website (defacement). This is often conducted by hackers who wish to express their political view (hacktivism). Another widely spread form of CNA is the Distributed-Denial-of-Service attack REVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010) (DDoS-attack),²⁶ which can cause delays in the data transfer process, the denial of access to computer systems or servers (e.g. the targeted websites or a email service) or result in the (only temporary) disabling of the targeted systems. The particular DDoS-techniques are as diverse as the – partly very effective – countermeasures²⁷ developed since 2000.\nHowever, the deletion or modification of data in a successfully intruded computer network can be more hazardous. Hackers can generate wrong information, for instance in the military environment the content of electronically transmitted orders, plans and maps or the localization data of military targets contained in a targeting-database.\nMoreover, it is possible that a CNA could – indirectly – cause death, physical injury or physical destruction of property. As far as chemical plants, nuclear power stations, oil refinery installations, gas store installations or electrical power distribution installations have or rely on computer-based control systems, these systems could be penetrated and manipulated. Thus, a CNA could cause the explosion of a nuclear power plant if the cooling systems were disabled via remote control. The same applies to computer-based control systems of transportation systems. By manipulation of the rail points, train derailments or collisions could be caused; penetration and minimal amendments to the programming of an air traffic control system could result in aircraft incidents. Therefore, the classification of CNO as a non-lethal weapon, as asserted by some scholars,²⁸ has to be challenged in this regard. Also, the general assertion made that CNO, in its current form would generally not violate LOAC, is questionable.²⁹ Above all, CNA can affect the functioning of a State, when manipulating or deleting data in computer systems of critical infrastructure systems. The list of critical infrastructure systems will slightly differ from State to State. By way of example, the following areas identified by the German Federal Office of Security of Information Technology (Bundesamt für Sicherheit in der Informationstechnik) can be considered as critical infrastructure systems:³⁰ transportation and traffic (postal services, local traffic, roads, rail system, aviation, sea and inland navigation); energy (nuclear plants, distribution and transfer systems of electricity, oil, gas); hazardous substances (chemical and biological agents, nuclear reactors); information and telecommunication technology; finance, currency and insurance (banks, insurance companies, financial service providers, stock markets); public utilities (health, emergency and rescue sector, disaster control, food and water supply, waste management); government, administration, justice, police, customs and armed forces.\nMany of these critical infrastructure systems are based on computer-based control systems, such as the generation and distribution of electricity or telecommunications. Some function entirely on the basis of an Internet connection, including the banking and stock exchange systems. Other areas are increasingly reliant on the Internet, for example the so-called e-justice and e-government. In any technologically highly developed, post-industrial State most of the critical infrastructure systems can be deemed to depend on the operability and efficiency of electronic data transfer. The devastating effects and the subsequent disruption of the ordre public caused by a CNA are limited only by the imagination of the reader. Therefore, cyber security plays a paramount role for the national security of many States and was noted as one of the major perils for the Alliance's security in NATO's Strategic Concept of 2010 (see supra I).\nThere is open source information available in the media on CNA being conducted during peacetime.\nThe only publicly known case, in which the attribution of a CNA to a particular State can be asserted, was the penetration and temporary disabling of Syrian air defence networks, especially the radar systems, by Israel on 6 September 2007, immediately followed by an airstrike by Israel's Air Force destroying Syria's Al Kibar nuclear reactor in Deir-Az-Zur.³¹ ³⁰ See the list of critical infrastructure systems, available at https://www.bsi.bund.de/cln_183/ContentBSI/Publikationen/Faltblaetter/F17KritischeInfrastruktur.html.\n³¹ Ben-David, supra note 8.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010) A more prominent case of a successful CNA against a State are the DDoS-attacks launched against several critical infrastructure systems in Estonia during the 27 April – 18 May 2007 timeframe. The “attacks”³² targeted websites and communication channels of the government and commercial services.³³ For example, the web-services of the major banks Hansapank and SEB Eesti Ühispank were (at one-time) interrupted for 1,5 hours;³⁴ the website of a governing coalition party was defaced;³⁵ emergency phone numbers were disengaged for a short time;³⁶ and three major Estonian Internet Service Providers and some online news providers were disconnected (although it is unclear for how long).³⁷ The estimated physical (because of the disengagement of emergency phone numbers) and economic damage caused by the DDoS-attacks remains unclear. The attacks most probably originated from the territory of the Russian Federation. Given the relatively simple DDoS-methods and the political context of the relocation of a Soviet war memorial in Tallinn, it is asserted that the “attackers” were politically motivated private persons (hacktivism).³⁸ Another example of successful CNA during peacetime are the defacement and DDoS-attacks launched against Lithuania between 28 June and 1 July 2008. The CNA may have been connected either to the amendment of Lithuania’s laws to prohibit the display of symbols of the Soviet Union or the singing of its anthem in public³⁹ or to the unilateral veto⁴⁰ against discussions on an EU energy partnership deal with Russian Federation. Over 300 Lithuanian websites were defaced, including those of the Government.⁴¹ Given the pro-Russian contents of the defacement, as well as the subject of the (unsolicited) spam emails “Hackers United against external threats to Russia”, the CNA is assumed to have originated with nationalistic, private hacker groups (hacktivism).42 On the contrary, the “Conficker” worm, reported to have been created by Russian criminals, was not aimed at State structures, as it spread worldwide, affecting both private and official networks. It did gain national interest of the victim States, when it began to affect governmental and military computer systems, including those of the British Parliament,43 and the French and British air forces and navies.44 The worm “Stuxnet”, which affected over 100.000 computer systems worldwide between June and September 2010, targeted industrial control systems of gas pipelines and power plants based on Siemens software, aiming to establish remote control of the systems and to hide any changes in the computer systems from the operators of the equipment.45 As the vast majority of the infections affected Iran’s critical infrastructure systems, in particular of the nuclear power plant near Bushehr, and the worm’s reach and complexity obviously required enormous personnel and budgetary investments as well as a considerable amount of time to write the code (in secrecy), the involvement of a foreign organization or State is suspected.46 Although there is no respective open source information, it must be assumed that, in the past, CNA were also successfully launched against NATO’s computer systems. The *Analysis and Recommendations of the Group of Experts on a New Strategic Concept for NATO* presented on 17 May 2010 noted: “Already, cyber attacks against NATO systems occur frequently, but most often below the threshold of political concern”.⁴⁷ Furthermore, CNA were conducted during times of armed conflict, as for example during *Operation Allied Force*⁴⁸ (24 March – 10 June 1999) launched by 10 NATO Member States⁴⁹ against Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. At the beginning of the operation, websites and the mailing system of NATO were blocked and infected by a virus (Melissa), apparently originating in Serbia.⁵⁰ Furthermore, some defacement attacks were launched by politically motivated individuals (hacktivism) from Serbia and Russia (*Black Hand, From Russia with Love, Russian Hacker Union*, etc.) against websites of NATO and NATO Member States.⁵¹ Equally, some hackers groups (politically) supporting the NATO operation (e.g. *Dutchthreat* or *Kosovo Hackers Group*) tried to infiltrate the governmental websites of Yugoslavia.⁵² Moreover, it is suspected that the President of the USA, *Bill Clinton*, did authorize the *Central Intelligence Agency* (CIA) to penetrate the computer systems of banks in Greece, Lebanon, Russia and Cyprus in order to clear the banking accounts of the President of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia *Slobodan Milošević*.⁵³ As the respective plans are said to have been ‘Foreign-made’ ‘Stuxnet’ Computer Virus’, *The Washington Post* online of 27 September 2010, available at http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/27/AR2010092706229.html.\n⁴⁷ NATO, *NATO 2020: Assured Security, Dynamic Engagement. It can be assumed that also in the near future CNO are very likely to be used merely in support of a conventional military operation, mainly military intelligence, reconnaissance and surveillance, or in order to influence the perception of a particular political conflict in the online media.\n## 2. Identification of the Origin and Attribution of Malicious CNO It will always be difficult to unequivocally identify the computer systems that malicious CNO originated from and to attribute the attack to a certain entity, group or a State.\nA cyber attack is distinguished by its rapidness. As soon as the attack is completed, the tracing of the data stream (so-called back-tracing) and news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/352059.stm; ‘CIA Ordered to Topple Milosevic’, BBC News online of 6 July 1999, available at http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/387463. stm; and F. Rötzer, ‘CIA im Crackerkrieg gegen Milosevich?’, heise online of 24 May 1999, available at http://www.heise.de/tp/r4/artikel/2/2874/1.html.\n⁵⁴ Id.\n⁵⁵ See Independent International Fact-Finding Mission on the Conflict in Georgia, Report, Vol. II., pp. 217 et seq., available at http://www.ceig.ch/pdf/IIFFMCG_Volume_II.pdf; and J. Markoff, ‘Before the Gunfire, Cyberattacks’, The New York Times online of 13 August 2008, available at http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/13/technology/13cyber.html?_r=2&amp;em.\n⁵⁶ For more details, see id.\n⁵⁷ Id.\nREVUE DE DROIT MILITAIRE ET DE DROIT DE LA GUERRE 49/1-2 (2010) thus the identification of the originating computer system are highly improbable. It is highly unlikely that hackers will leave any tangible evidence, for example in the protocols of the intrusion detection systems of the attacked network, as such evidence in these protocols is easy to delete once the network is penetrated.\nMoreover, and further aggravating the issue, a cyber-attack can be conducted “anonymously”, for example by using one of the (often) free of charge anonymisation services offered on the Internet which would hide the unique characteristics of the hackers’ computer system. These unique characteristics are the so-called IP address⁵⁸ as well as other technical data⁵⁹ a computer sends while connected to the Internet.\n⁵⁸ An IP address (Internet Protocol number) is a twelve digit number, which identifies a computer or another network device during an Internet session. An IP data package is the basic element of data transmission via the Internet. It comprises: a header (containing information on the source, destination, status and fragmentation of the transmitted data) and a payload (containing the transmitted data). At the very beginning of the Internet, the IANA (see supra note 1) assigned static IP addresses, i.e. IP addresses permanently assigned to a particular user, to companies, organizations, universities and also to individuals. The assignment of IP addresses to individual users or of IP address ranges to Internet Access Providers is now regulated by ICANN (see supra note 1). Since February 2005, ICANN delegates this task to five Regional Internet Registries (RIR), i.e. regional organisations assigning IP addresses. These are AfriNIC (Africa), APNIC (Asia and Pacific), ARIN (North America), LACNIC (Latin America and Caribbean Region) and RIPE NCC (Europe, Near East and Central Asia). The regional organisations assign the IP addresses to local organisations, mainly to Internet Service Providers (e.g. yahoo, gmail etc). Usually, an Internet user receives from the pool of IP addresses at the disposal of an Access Provider a specific (dynamic) IP address for the particular Internet session only. After the particular Internet session the dynamic IP address is assigned to another user and client of the respective Access Provider. At present, the so-called static IP-addresses are only being used for leased Internet-lines of major corporations and other entities.\n⁵⁹ These include: Media Access Control address (MAC address) or – for the operating system Apple – the Airport ID of a computer (order of numbers, which clearly identifies a computer hardware); Address Resolution Protocol (ARP, details on the assignment of a MAC address or Airport ID to an IP address); Service Set Identity (SSID, details on the network name); Wired Equivalent Privacy Protocol (WEP, coded details about the network); as well as details on the operating system and its adjustments. These details are – if not blocked – automatically transferred during the Internet session to any computer requesting this information by a so-called PING (Packet InterNet Grouper). A PING is computer software sending an ICMP-Echo-Request data package to the destination address of the host which is to be scanned, i.e. to the IP address, to the Domain Name System name (DNS name) or to the Network Basic Input Output System name (NetBIOS name) of the targeted host. The targeted system automatically responds by an ICMP-Echo-Reply, if – according to the usual adjustments of the system – the system supports the ICMP package.\nMILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010) Furthermore, the Internet offers possibilities for deception in regard to the identity of the hackers' computer systems. It is perfectly possible to feign someone else's IP address and other technical data (so-called malicious misrepresentation or spoofing) and thus to operate in the Internet under someone else's\"cyber-identity\". The connection to the Internet can also be established via a mobile phone or other device with a feigned identity number. Additionally, the data stream can be conducted through the whole globe via a chain of computers of numerous unsuspecting individuals, if so-called zombie software (partly offered free of charge on the Internet) has been secretly installed on the respective computers by using Trojans. One of these computers could subsequently be misused as the sender of the data stream (so-called remote control). Thus, in the case of a cyber attack, even after a back tracing of the malicious data stream, the victim can seldom be sure as of the identification and geographical location of the computer system the attack originated from.\nAbove all, even if a malicious data stream of a cyber attack would indeed be successfully back-traced to the hackers' computer systems, it will – highly probable – remain unproven which individuals of which citizenship and on who's orders were operating the systems identified. Therefore, the attribution of a cyber attack to a certain individual, group, entity or State will most probably be based on unproven suspicions or indications only.\nConsequently, it will be very unlikely to recognize at first sight – and probably even after detailed technical analysis – whether the attack was conducted by a mischievous teenager, by a criminal (including a terrorist), by a group with extremist or terrorist background or by the adversary Party in an armed conflict.\nThese uncertainties will surely add to the complexity of both the legal analysis of a cyber attack and the victim's decision on choosing a subsequent course of action. Considering the difficulty in identifying and locating the hackers' computer systems and – most importantly – attributing the attack, in most cases it will remain in doubt whether national police forces and public prosecutors or, in the framework of international judicial cooperation, the police forces and public prosecutors of a foreign State, or the armed forces (in the case the attack occurs during an already existing armed conflict and is believed to have originated with a party to the armed conflict, or in the case the effects of the cyber-attack are comparable to a conventional armed attack and trigger the right to self-defence) retain main responsibility to deal with the case.\n## 3. CNO in Modern Warfare The significance of CNO for the conduct of military operations is manifold.\nWhilst most armed conflicts in this day and age are occurring in regions that are technologically less sophisticated (e.g. Afghanistan, Sudan or Chad), this does not result in the irrelevance of the Internet and of CNO. It must be taken into consideration that, in regard to communication abilities and collection of open source information, the parties to armed conflicts in less well developed regions are also essentially dependent on – aside from radio traffic – wireless Internet connectivity, as other communication and information systems (e.g. telecommunication media, print media, telephone lines) are often non-existent.\nIt is especially evident in the context of so-called asymmetric warfare and in the hands of non-state actors, for instance terrorists, that CNO can be a powerful weapon, primarily against post-industrial States and their potent armed forces. More than ever, post-industrial States have technologically highly developed armed forces at their disposal, which correspondingly react most sensitively to technical disorder. It is the dependence on the technology which makes them extremely vulnerable to a cyber attack.\nAs CNO can be conducted from any place in the world by as little as a few experts and, in addition, are extraordinarily inexpensive when compared with conventional military operations, they offer a particularly practical and extremely powerful\"weapon\". Therefore, all aspects of CNO (see supra II.1) show an increasing significance in the context of national as well as of international security.\nAs the Head of the NATO Computer Incident Response Capability Co-ordination Centre stated already in 2008:\"Cyber war can become a very effective global problem because it is low-risk, low-cost, highly effective and easily globally deployable. It is almost an ideal weapon that nobody can ignore\".60 MILITARY LAW AND THE LAW OF WAR REVIEW 49/1-2 (2010) ## III. Legal Analysis of CNO Although some scholars plead for a general prohibition of CNO, currently such a ban does not exist.⁶¹ However, many international and domestic legal restrictions do apply to CNO – a fact which makes a legal analysis a complex undertaking.\nApart from the fundamental principle of public international law, namely the prohibition of the threat or use of force in international relations, a number of specific areas of public international law may apply to CNO. As data packages pass through the territory of several States when sent via the Internet, the provisions of territorial sovereignty must be considered. Also, data manipulations might – under certain circumstances – be judged as intervention in domestic affairs of a State, which would be considered illegal under public international law. Further, because satellite technology is involved, space law and especially treaties relating to satellites must be considered. As CNO can interfere with telecommunication systems and always result in data amendments in the working storage of the attacked computer system, both international telecommunications law and international copyright law (in regard to software) require a thorough analysis. In case human rights treaty law is generally applicable, their respective provisions must be considered, especially in regard to secrecy of correspondence, telecommunications and data protection, as well as to the right to receive and impart information and ideas. Restraints for CNO can further result from the provisions of diplomatic and consular law, whenever diplomatic or consular computer systems are involved. Furthermore, it has been asserted that international environmental law principles of good neighbourhood and of the prevention of significant trans-boundary harm would be applicable to CNO in analogy.⁶² In addition, the provisions of ⁶¹ A. However, first of all, it must be examined under which conditions LOAC applies to CNO (1).\n## 1. The Applicability of the Laws of Armed Conflict According to common Article 2 of the GCs, LOAC applies to all cases of declared war or of any other armed conflict which may arise between two or more of the High Contracting Parties, even if the state of war is not recognized by one of them. The Convention shall also apply to all cases of partial or total occupation of the territory of a High Contracting Party, even if the said occupation meets with no armed resistance.\nIn practice, armed conflicts surely can be considered as the main case of application of LOAC. Pursuant to the prevailing opinion an is taken by the (non-binding) OECD Guidelines for the Security of Information Systems of 1992, which call for cooperation of States (Principle 6) in the area of comprehensive protection of information systems (Principle 4), and which stipulate an imperative of deliberation in the use of information systems (Principle 3), see OECD Doc. OCDE/GD(92)190. However, an analogous application of international environmental law provisions is not convincing because of the lack of an “unintended omission” or of the absence of regulation.
